{{multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=November 2012}} {{essay|date=November 2012}} }}
{{infobox martial art term |title = Blocking |pic = High kick block.jpg |picsize = |piccap = A fighter raises his hands to block the opponent's [[roundhouse kick]]. }}In [[martial arts]], '''blocking''' is the act of stopping or deflecting an opponent's attack for the purpose of preventing injurious contact with the body. A block usually consists of placing a limb across the line of the attack.
== Examples in specific arts == Styles and types of blocking, as well as terminology, vary widely among the various martial arts. In Japanese martial arts such as [[Karate]], these techniques are referred to as ''uke waza''. Examples include ''age uke'' (rising block) and ''shuto uke'' (knife hand guarding block). In Korean martial arts such as [[Taekwondo]], these techniques are referred to as ''makgi''(막기), with some examples being ''chukyeo makgi'' (rising block) and ''sonkal daebi makgi'' (knifehand guarding block). Some martial arts, such as [[Capoeira]], reject blocking techniques completely as they consider them too inefficient. In Capoeira, they use evasion instead of blocking.
==Types of blocks==
=== Inside blocks === An inside block deflects a [[Strike (attack)|strike]] away from the defender and away from the attacker. For example, against a straight punch to the face, an inside forearm block would aim to meet the inside of the forearm of the attacker, pushing the punch outward, leaving the opponents facing each other which also helps in counterattack.
=== Outside blocks === An outside block deflects a [[Strike (attack)|strike]] away from the defender and across the attacker. For example, against a straight punch to the face, an outside forearm block would aim to meet the outside forearm of the attacker, pushing the punch outward, leaving the defender slightly to the side of the strike causing it to miss. Typically, because of the angles involved, inward blocks are used against attacks aimed at the torso.
=== High blocks === [[Image:EVD-kumite-042.jpg|thumb|A high block against a face punch]] A high block deflects a downward strike such as a hammer fist, a stick or a face punch from a taller opponent. The chamber starts low with the hand in a relaxed fist across the abdomen with the palm facing inward and in high block, face punch should be blocked in diagonal shape
=== Low blocks === [[Image:EVD-kata-230.jpg|thumb|A low block against a low [[crescent kick]]]] A low block deflects an inward strike directed at the stomach or ribs such as a [[roundhouse kick]].
=== Parries === {{further|Parry (fencing)}} Parries are executed against the attacker by quickly pushing their arm or leg away to the right or left side(as it is considered as a block) and counterattacking when the procedure is done.
===Other types of blocks and alternatives=== More complex blocks include the circular block, X block, high X block, twin forearm guarding block, hooking block, and pole block.
Offensive techniques can also be used to block. For example, a [[kick]] or palm [[strike (attack)|strike]] can be used to neutralize an incoming blow. It is also common to use the knee to block leg attacks from an opponent.
Blocks are considered by some to be the most direct and least subtle of defensive techniques. Other ways of avoiding attack include evasion, trapping, slipping and deflection of the oncoming attack; this approach is often referred to as the application of 'soft' techniques (see [[hard and soft (martial arts)]]).
==External links== *[http://www.uk-martialartist.co.uk/articles/animatedkarateblocks.php Animated examples of Karate blocks] *[http://exershare.com/video/Blocking__Doding_Techniques_1.aspx Examples of blocking and dodging]
{{karate schools}} {{martial arts}}

{{lead too short|date=September 2017}} '''Blood doping''' is the practice of boosting the number of [[red blood cells]] in the bloodstream in order to enhance athletic performance. Because such blood cells carry [[oxygen]] from the [[lung]]s to the [[muscle]]s, a higher concentration in the blood can improve an athlete’s [[aerobic capacity]] (VO<sub>2</sub> max) and [[endurance]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Jelkmann | first1 = W. | last2 = Lundby | first2 = C. | year = 2011 | title = Blood doping and its detection | url = | journal = Blood | volume = 118 | issue = 9| pages = 2395–404 | doi = 10.1182/blood-2011-02-303271 | pmid = 21652677 }}</ref> Many methods of blood doping are illegal, particularly in professional sports.
==Background== [[File:Achieving Maximum Aerobic Capacity.png|thumb|480px|Fig. 1 Achieving Maximum Aerobic Capacity]] Blood doping is defined as the use of illicit products (e.g. [[erythropoietin]] (EPO), darbepoetin-alfa, [[hypoxia-inducible factor]] (HIF) stabilizers) and methods (e.g. increase aerobic capacity by maximizing the uptake of O<sub>2</sub>) in order to enhance the O<sub>2</sub> transport of the body to the muscles.<ref name="jelkmann1">{{cite journal | last1 = Jelkmann | first1 = Wolfgang | last2 = Lundby | first2 = Carsten | year = 2013 | title = Blood Doping and its Detection | url = | journal = Blood | volume = 118 | issue = 9| pages = 2395–2402 }}</ref>
The body undergoes aerobic respiration in order to provide sufficient delivery of O<sub>2</sub> to the exercising skeletal muscles and the main determining factors are shown in figure 1. The rate of maximum O<sub>2</sub> uptake (O<sub>2</sub>max) depends on cardiac output, O<sub>2</sub> extraction and hemoglobin mass. The cardiac output of an athlete is difficult to manipulate during competitions and the distribution of cardiac output is at the maximum rate (i.e. 80%) during competitions. In addition, the O<sub>2</sub> extraction is approximately 90% at maximal exercise. Therefore, the only method to enhance the physical performance left is to increase the O<sub>2</sub> content in the artery by enhancing the hemoglobin mass. In other words, hemoglobin concentration and blood volume contribute to hemoglobin mass.<ref name="jelkmann1"/>
==Methods==
===Drug treatments=== Many forms of blood doping stem from the misuse of pharmaceuticals. These drug treatments have been created for clinical use to increase the oxygen delivery when the human body is not able to do so naturally.
====Erythropoietin====
[[Erythropoietin]] (EPO) is a glycoprotein hormone produced by the interstitial fibroblasts in the kidney that signal for erythropoiesis in bone marrow. The increased activity of a Hemocytoblast (RBC stem cell) allows the blood to have a greater carrying capacity for oxygen. EPO was first developed to counteract the effects of chemotherapy and radiation therapy for cancer patients.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Buemi|first=M|author2=Caccamo, C |author3=Nostro, L |author4=Cavallaro, E |author5=Floccari, F |author6= Grasso, G |title=Brain and cancer: the protective role of erythropoietin|journal=Medicinal Research Reviews|date=Mar 2005|volume=25|issue=2|pages=245–59|pmid=15389732 |doi=10.1002/med.20012}}</ref> EPO also stimulates increased wound healing.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Liu|first=S|author2=Ren, J |author3=Hong, Z |author4=Yan, D |author5=Gu, G |author6=Han, G |author7=Wang, G |author8=Ren, H |author9=Chen, J |author10= Li, J |title=Efficacy of erythropoietin combined with enteral nutrition for the treatment of anemia in Crohn's disease: a prospective cohort study|journal=Nutrition in Clinical Practice : Official Publication of the American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition|date=Feb 2013|volume=28|issue=1|pages=120–7|pmid=23064018 |doi=10.1177/0884533612462744}}</ref> Because of its physiological side effects, particularly increased hematocrit, EPO has become a drug with abuse potential by professional and amateur cyclists.
====Hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) stabilizer====
Hypoxia-inducible factor stabilizer (HIF stabilizer) is a pharmaceutical used to treat chronic kidney disease. Like most transcription factors, the HIF transcription factor is responsible for the expression of a protein. The HIF stabilizer activates the activity of EPO due to anemia induced hypoxia, metabolic stress, and vasculogenesis—the creation of new blood vessels.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Haase|first=VH|title=Hypoxia-inducible factors in the kidney|journal=American Journal of Physiology. Renal Physiology|date=Aug 2006|volume=291|issue=2|pages=F271–81|pmid=16554418|doi=10.1152/ajprenal.00071.2006|pmc=4232221}}</ref> HIF stabilizers as used by cyclists in combination with cobalt chloride/desferrioxamine stimulate and de-regulate the natural production of erythropoietin hormone.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hoffman|first=Ronald | display-authors = | last2 = et al |title=Hematology : basic principles and practice|year=2009|publisher=Churchill Livingstone/Elsevier|location=Philadelphia, PA|isbn=978-0443067150|pages=Ch68|edition=5th}}</ref> At physiologically low PaO<sub>2</sub> around 40 mmHg, EPO is released from the kidneys to increase hemoglobin transportation.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Joyner|first=MJ|title=VO2MAX, blood doping, and erythropoietin|journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine|date=Jun 2003|volume=37|issue=3|pages=190–1|pmid=12782539|pmc=1724644|doi=10.1136/bjsm.37.3.190}}</ref> The combination of drugs consistently releases EPO due to increased transcription at the cellular level. The effect wears off when the HIF stabilizers, cobalt chloride/desferrioxamine is excreted and/or decayed by the body.
====Myo-inositol trispyrophosphate (ITPP)====
[[Myo-inositol trispyrophosphate]] (ITPP), also known as [[List of pharmaceutical compound number prefixes|compound number]] OXY111A, is an [[allosteric effector]] of hemoglobin which causes a rightward shift in the [[oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve]], increasing the amount of oxygen released from red blood cells into surrounding tissue during each passage through the cardiovascular system.<ref name=pmid19204295>{{cite journal | pmid = 19204295 | year = 2009 | author1 = Biolo | first1 = A | title = Enhanced exercise capacity in mice with severe heart failure treated with an allosteric effector of hemoglobin, myo-inositol trispyrophosphate | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A | volume = 106 | issue = 6 | pages = 1926–1929 | last2 = Greferath | first2 = R | last3 = Siwik | first3 = DA | last4 = Qin | first4 = F | last5 = Valsky | first5 = E | last6 = Fylaktakidou | first6 = KC | last7 = Pothukanuri | first7 = S | last8 = Duarte | first8 = CD | last9 = Schwarz | first9 = RP | last10 = Lehn | first10 = JM | last11 = Nicolau | first11 = C | last12 = Colucci | first12 = WS | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0812381106 | pmc=2644140}}</ref> ITPP has been a subject of anti-doping research in both humans<ref name=pmid25070041>{{cite journal | pmid = 25070041 | year = 2014 | author1 = Görgens | first1 = C | title = Screening and confirmation of myo-inositol trispyrophosphate (ITPP) in human urine by hydrophilic interaction liquid chromatography high resolution / high accuracy mass spectrometry for doping control purposes | journal = Drug Test Anal. | volume = 6 | issue = 11–12 | pages = 1102–1107 | last2 = Guddat | first2 = S | last3 = Schänzer | first3 = W | last4 = Thevis | first4 = M | doi = 10.1002/dta.1700 }}</ref> and [[racehorses]].<ref name=pmid23733541>{{cite journal | pmid = 23733541 | year = 2014 | author1 = Lam | first1 = G | title = Detection of myo-inositol tris pyrophosphate (ITPP) in equine following an administration of ITPP | journal = Drug Test Anal. | volume = 6 | issue = 3 | pages = 268–276 | last2 = Zhao | first2 = S | last3 = Sandhu | first3 = J | last4 = Yi | first4 = R | last5 = Loganathan | first5 = D | last6 = Morrissey | first6 = B | doi = 10.1002/dta.1473 }}</ref>
===Blood transfusion===
Blood transfusions can be traditionally classified as [[autologous]], where the blood donor and transfusion recipient are the same, or as [[allogeneic]]/homologous, where the blood is transfused into someone other than the donor. Blood transfusion begins by the withdrawal of 1 to 4 units of blood (1 unit = 450 ml of blood) several weeks before competition. The blood is centrifuged, the plasma components are immediately reinfused, and the corpuscular elements, principally red blood cells (RBCs), are stored refrigerated at 4 °C or frozen at −80 °C.<ref name="mcardle1">McArdle WD, Katch FI, Katch VL. Exercise Physiology. In McArdle WD, Katch FI, Katch VL, Eds. Energy, Nutrition, and Human Performance. 2nd Ed. Pp 409–411. Philadelphia: Lea and Febiger, 1986.</ref> As blood stored by refrigeration displays a steady decline in the number of RBCs, a substantial percentage, up to 40%, of the stored RBCs may not be viable.<ref name="gledhill">{{cite journal | last1 = Gledhill | first1 = N | year = 1982 | title = Blood doping and related issues: A brief review | url = | journal = Med Sci Sports Exerc | volume = 14 | issue = 3| pages = 183–189 | doi=10.1249/00005768-198203000-00005}}</ref> The freezing process, conversely, limits the aging of the cells, allowing the storage of the blood for up to 10 years with a 10% to 15% loss of RBCs.<ref name ="ghaphery1">{{cite journal | last1 = Ghaphery | first1 = NA | year = 1995 | title = Performance-enhancing drugs | url = | journal = Orthop Clin North Am | volume = 26 | issue = | pages = 433–442 }}</ref> Stored RBCs are then reinfused, usually 1 to 7 days before a high-endurance event. As a significant amount of iron is removed by each autologous transfusion, an adequate time for recovery of not less than 3 days from the last donation, and appropriate iron supplements, are usually required for patients undergoing autologous donations. Nearly 50% of autologous donations are not used by the donor and are discarded, as current standards do not allow transfusion of these units to another patient for safety reasons.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
===Blood substitutes===
Biochemical and biotechnological development has allowed novel approaches to this issue, in the form of engineered O<sub>2</sub> carriers, widely known as “blood substitutes.” The blood substitutes currently available are chiefly polymerized haemoglobin solutions or [[Hemoglobin-based oxygen carriers|haemoglobin-based oxygen carriers]] (HBOCs) and perfluorocarbons (PFCs).<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal | last1 = Scott | first1 = MG | last2 = Kucik | first2 = DF | last3 = Goodnough | first3 = LT | last4 = Monk | first4 = TG | year = 1997 | title = Blood substitutes: Evolution and future applications | url = | journal = Clin Chem | volume = 43 | issue = | pages = 1724–1731 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ma | first1 = Z | last2 = Monk | first2 = TG | last3 = Goodnough | first3 = LT | last4 = McClellan | first4 = A | last5 = Gawryl | first5 = M | last6 = Clark | first6 = T | last7 = Moreira | first7 = P | last8 = Keipert | first8 = PE | last9 = Scott | first9 = MG | year = 1997 | title = Effect of hemoglobin- and Perflubron-based oxygen carriers on common clinical laboratory tests | url = | journal = Clin Chem | volume = 43 | issue = | pages = 1732–1737 }}</ref>
====Hemoglobin-based oxygen carriers (HBOCs)====
[[Hemoglobin-based oxygen carriers]] are intra/ inter-molecularly engineered human or animal hemoglobins, only optimized for oxygen delivery and longer intravascular circulation. The presence of [[2,3-diphosphoglycerate]] within erythrocytes maintains the normal affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen. HBOCs do not contain erythrocytes and lose this interaction, thus, unmodified human HBOC solutions have a very high oxygen affinity which compromises their function. Chemical methods developed to overcome this problem have resulted in carriers that effectively release oxygen at the physiological pO<sub>2</sub> of peripheral tissues.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lieberthal | first1 = W | last2 = Fuhro | first2 = R | last3 = Freedman | first3 = JE | last4 = Toolan | first4 = G | last5 = Loscalzo | first5 = J | last6 = Valeri | first6 = CR | year = 1999 | title = O-raffinose cross-linking markedly reduces systemic and renal vasoconstrictor effects of unmodified human hemoglobin | url = | journal = J Pharmacol Exp Ther | volume = 288 | issue = | pages = 1278–1287 }}</ref>
A common feature of all HBOCs is their resistance to dissociate when dissolved in media, which contrasts hemoglobin of natural dissociation under non-physiological conditions. HBOCs may hypothetically supply greater benefits to athletes than those provided by the equivalent hemoglobin in traditional RBC infusion. Recent developments have shown that HBOCs are not only simple RBC substitutes, but highly effective O<sub>2</sub> donors in terms of tissue oxygenation. Additional effects include increases in blood serum iron, [[ferritin]], and Epo;<ref>184Hughes GS Jr, Francome SF, Antal EJ, Adams WJ, Locker PK, Yancey EP, Jacobs EE Jr. "Hematologic effects of a novel hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier in normal male and female subjects. ''J Lab Clin Med'' 1995; 126: 444–451.</ref> up to 20% increased diffusion of oxygen and improved exercise capacity;<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hughes | first1 = GS Jr | last2 = Antal | first2 = EJ | last3 = Locker | first3 = PK | last4 = Francom | first4 = SF | last5 = Adams | first5 = WJ | last6 = Jacobs | first6 = EE Jr | year = 1996 | title = Physiology and pharmacokinetics of a novel hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier in humans | url = | journal = Crit Care Med | volume = 24 | issue = 5| pages = 756–764 | doi=10.1097/00003246-199605000-00006}}</ref> increased CO<sub>2</sub> production; and lower lactic acid generation in anaerobic activity.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hughes | first1 = GS Jr | last2 = Yancey | first2 = EP | last3 = Albrecht | first3 = R | last4 = Locker | first4 = PK | last5 = Francom | first5 = SF | last6 = Orringer | first6 = EP | last7 = Antal | first7 = EJ | last8 = Jacobs | first8 = EE Jr | year = 1995 | title = Hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier preserves submaximal exercise capacity in humans | url = | journal = Clin Pharmacol Ther | volume = 58 | issue = 4| pages = 434–443 | doi=10.1016/0009-9236(95)90057-8| pmid = 7586936 }}</ref> HBOCs have been shown in trials to be extremely dangerous in humans. Because [[Haemoglobin-based oxygen carriers]] increase both the risk of death and risk of myocardial infarction clinical trials were ended. They are not commercially available in the US or Europe and there is no approved use for them.<ref name="Natanson C, Kern SJ, Lurie P, Banks SM, Wolfe SM 2008 2304–12">{{cite journal |vauthors=Natanson C, Kern SJ, Lurie P, Banks SM, Wolfe SM |title=Cell-free hemoglobin-based blood substitutes and risk of myocardial infarction and death: a meta-analysis |journal=JAMA |volume=299 |issue=19 |pages=2304–12 |date=May 2008 |pmid=18443023 |doi=10.1001/jama.299.19.jrv80007 |url=}}</ref>
====Perfluorocarbons (PFCs)====
PFCs, also known as [[fluorocarbons]], are inert, water-insoluble, synthetic compounds, consisting primarily of carbon and fluorine atoms bonded together in strong C–F bonds. PFCs are substantially clear and colorless liquid emulsions that are heterogeneous in molecular weight, surface area, electronic charge, and viscosity; their high content of electron-dense fluorine atoms results in little intramolecular interaction and low surface tension, making such substances excellent solvents for gases, especially oxygen and carbon dioxide.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Some of these molecules can dissolve 100 times more oxygen than plasma. PFCs are naturally hydrophobic and need to be emulsified to be injected intravenously. Since PFCs dissolve rather than bind oxygen, their capacity to serve as a blood substitute is determined principally by the pO<sub>2</sub> gradients in the lung and at the target tissue. Therefore, their oxygen transport properties differ substantially from those of whole blood and, especially, from those of RBCs.<ref name="spahn1">{{cite journal | last1 = Spahn | first1 = DR | year = 1999 | title = Blood substitutes. Artificial oxygen carriers: Perfluorocarbon emulsions | url = | journal = Crit Care | volume = 3 | issue = 5| pages = R93–R97 | doi=10.1186/cc364| pmid = 11094488 | pmc = 137239 }}</ref> At a conventional ambient pO<sub>2</sub> of 135 mmHg, the oxygen content of 900 ml/l perfluorocarbon is less than 50 ml/l, whereas an optimal oxygen content of 160 ml/l, which is still lower than that of whole blood in normal conditions, can be achieved only by a pO<sub>2</sub> greater than 500 mmHg. In practice, at a conventional alveolar pO<sub>2</sub> of 135 mmHg, PFCs will not be able to provide sufficient oxygenation to peripheral tissues.<ref name="spahn1" /><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Riess | first1 = JG | year = 2005 | title = Understanding the fundamentals of perfluorocarbons and perfluorocarbon emulsions relevant to ''in vivo'' oxygen delivery | url = | journal = Artif Cells Blood Substit Immobil Biotechnol | volume = 33 | issue = 1| pages = 47–63 | doi=10.1081/bio-200046659| pmid = 15768565 }}</ref>
Due to their small size, PFCs are able to permeate circulation where erythrocytes may not flow. In tiny capillaries, PFCs produce the greatest benefit, as they increase local oxygen delivery much more efficiently than would be expected from the increase in oxygen content in larger arteries.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Patel | first1 = S | last2 = Mehra | first2 = A | year = 1998 | title = Modeling of oxygen transport in blood-perfluorocarbon emulsion mixtures: Part II: Tissue oxygenation | url = | journal = Asaio J | volume = 44 | issue = 3| pages = 157–165 | doi=10.1097/00002480-199805000-00007}}</ref> In addition, as gases are in the dissolved state within PFCs, it pO<sub>2</sub> promotes efficient oxygen delivery to peripheral tissues. Since the mid-1980s, improvements in both oxygen capacity and emulsion properties of PFCs have led to the development of second-generation PFC-based oxygen carriers; two PFC products are currently being tested in phase III clinical trials.<ref>Hill SE. "Oxygen therapeutics. Current concepts. ''Can J Anaesth'' 2001; 48 (4 Suppl): S32–S40</ref>
===Cobalt Chloride Administration=== Transition metal complexes are widely known to play important roles in [[erythropoiesis]]; as such, inorganic supplementation is proving to be an emerging technique in blood doping. Particularly of note is the cobalt complex, [[cobalamin]] (Vitamin B<sub>12</sub>) commonly used as a dietary supplement. Cobalamin is an important complex used in the manufacture of red blood cells and thus was of interest for potential use in blood doping. Experimental evidence, however, has shown that cobalamin has no effect on erythropoiesis in the absence of a red blood cell/oxygen deficiency.<ref name="jelkmann2">{{cite journal | last1 = Jelkmann | first1 = W | year = | title = The disparate roles of cobalt in erythropoiesis, and doping relevance | url = | journal = Open Journal of Hematology | volume = 2012 | issue = | pages = 3–6 }}</ref> These results seem to confirm much of what is already known about the functioning of cobalamin.<ref name="jelkmann2" /> The signaling pathway that induces erythropoietin secretion and subsequently red blood cell manufacture using cobalamin is O<sub>2</sub> dependent. Erythropoietin is only secreted in the kidneys when there is an O<sub>2</sub> deficiency, as such, RBC manufacture is independent of the amount of cobalamin administered when there is no O<sub>2</sub> deficiency. Accordingly, cobalamin is of little to no value in blood doping.
More potent for use in blood doping is Co<sup>2+</sup> (administered as [[Cobalt(II) chloride]], CoCl<sub>2</sub>). Cobalt chloride has been known to be useful in treating anemic patients.<ref name="lippi1">{{cite journal | last1 = Lippi | first1 = G. | last2 = Franchini | first2 = M. | last3 = Guidi | first3 = G. | year = 2005 | title = Cobalt chloride administration in athletes: a new perspective in blood doping? | url = | journal = Br J Sports Med | volume = 39 | issue = 11| pages = 872–873 | doi=10.1136/bjsm.2005.019232 | pmid=16244201 | pmc=1725077}}</ref><ref name="jelkmann3">{{cite journal | last1 = Jelkmann | first1 = W | year = 2007 | title = Novel Erythropoietic Agents: A Threat to Sportsmanship | url = | journal = Medician Sportiva | volume = 11 | issue = 2| pages = 32–34 | doi=10.2478/v10036-007-0007-1}}</ref> Recent experimental evidence has proved the efficacy of cobalt chloride in blood doping.<ref name="lippi1" /> Studies into the action of this species have shown that Co<sup>2+</sup> induces hypoxia like responses, the most relevant response being erythropoiesis. Co<sup>2+</sup> induces this response by binding to the N-terminus (loop helix loop domain) of the Hypoxia inducing transcription factors HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and thus stabilizes these protein complexes.<ref name="jelkmann3" /><ref name="kanayaa1">{{cite journal | last1 = Kanayaa | first1 = K. | last2 = Kamitania | first2 = T. | year = 2003 | title = pVHL-independent ubiquitination of HIF1a and its stabilization by cobalt ion | url = | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 306 | issue = 3| pages = 750–755 | doi=10.1016/s0006-291x(03)01041-6}}</ref> Under normal O<sub>2</sub> conditions, HIFs are destabilized as proline and asparagine residues are hydroxylated by HIF-α hydroxylases, these unstable HIFs are subsequently degraded following a ubiquitin-proteosome pathway, as such, they cannot then bind and activate transcription of genes encoding Erythropoietin (EPO).<ref name="jelkmann3" /><ref name="kanayaa1" /> With Co<sup>2+</sup> stabilization, degradation is prevented and genes encoding EPO can then be activated. The mechanism for this Co<sup>2+</sup> N terminus stabilization is not yet fully understood. In addition to N-terminus binding, it has also been hypothesized that replacement of Fe<sup>2+</sup> by Co<sup>2+</sup> in the hydroxylase active site could be a contributing factor to the stabilizing action of Co<sup>2+</sup>.<ref name="jelkmann3" /> It is understood however, is that Co<sup>2+</sup> binding permits Ubiquitin binding but prevents proteosomal degradation.<ref name="kanayaa1" />
==Detection of blood doping ==
===Detection for homologous blood doping=== In 2004, a test for detection allogeneic/homologous blood transfusion doping was implemented. Flow Cytometry is the method of choice. By examining markers on the surface of blood cells, the method can determine whether blood from more than one person is present in an athlete’s circulation. The test utilizes 12 antisera directed against the blood group antigens, obtained from donor plasma. The antigens are labeled with secondary antibodies, which are conjugated with [[phycoerythrin]] to label IgG or IgM-coated RBCs and enhance the detection by flow cytometry <ref name="jelkmann1" /><ref name="nelson1">{{cite journal | last1 = Nelson | first1 = M. | display-authors = etal | year = 2003 | title = Proof of Homologous Blood Transfusion through Quantification of Blood Group Antigens | url = | journal = Haematologica | volume = 88 | issue = | page = 12841295 }}</ref> The [[flow cytometry]] is able to detect minor variance in blood group antigens. The assessment was able to distinguish the blood of subjects who had earlier received at least one unit of allogeneic blood.<ref name="nelson1" /> This technique is able to detect small (<5%) populations of cells that are antigenically distinct from an individual’s own RBCs.<ref name="nelson1" />
===Detection for autologous blood doping=== Autologous blood doping detection is done indirectly via CO rebreathing technique to measure the nonphysiologic increases in Hb mass. The principle of CO rebreathing method used currently requires an O<sub>2</sub>-CO gas mixture inhalation for about 10-15mins.<ref name="schmidt1">{{cite journal | last1 = Schmidt | first1 = Walter | last2 = Prommer | first2 = Nicole | year = 2005 | title = The Optimised CO-Rebreathing Method: A New Tool to Determine Total Haemogloblin Mass Routinely | url = | journal = Eur J Appl Physiol | volume = 95 | issue = 5–6| pages = 486–495 | doi=10.1007/s00421-005-0050-3| pmid = 16222540 }}</ref> By measuring the difference in [[carboxyhemoglobin]] concentration (HbCO) before and after rebreathing, the volume of CO and the binding capacity of Hb for CO ( 1.39ml g-1), total Hb mass can be calculated.<ref name="schmidt1"/> This detection method is problematic for an athlete as it is not desirable to breathe in CO shortly before a competition, which may potentially affect their performances.
===Detection of blood hemoglobin-based oxygen carrier=== Detection method for hemoglobin-based oxygen carriers (i.e. Oxyglobulin) is done in four separate steps. Step one involves the elimination of abundance proteins in the blood samples by immunodepletion (i.e. Proteo Prep 20 plasma immunodepletion kit).<ref name="staub1">{{cite journal | last1 = Staub | first1 = S. | display-authors = etal | year = 2010 | title = Analysis of Hemoglobin-Based Oxygen Carriers by CE-UV'Vis and CE-ESI-TOF/MS | url = | journal = Electrophoresis | volume = 31 | issue = 7| pages = 1241–1247 | doi=10.1002/elps.200900513| pmid = 20196028 }}</ref> This process ensures that other proteins (i.e. albumin and immunoglobulin) do not interfere with [[capillary electrophoresis]] (CE) separation by changing the ionization. Second step, CE separation is done under certain condition, in this case background electrolyte consisting of ammonium formate (75mM at pH 9.5) in order to provide sufficient resolution between HBOC and Hb.<ref name="staub1"/> Third step, UV/Vis detection was performed at 415 nm to selectively detect HBOC and HB. Fourth step, [[Time-of-flight]] (TOF) or [[Mass spectrometer]](MS) allowed increase accuracy in selectivity between hemoproteins and other proteins and definite determination of HBOC uptake.<ref name="staub2">{{cite journal | last1 = Staub | first1 = S. | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = 2010 | title = Blood Doping Detection- A New Analytical Approach with Capillary Electrophoresis | url = | journal = CHIMIA | volume = 64 | issue = 12| page = 886 | doi=10.2533/chimia.2010.886}}</ref> The detection limits for CE-UV/Vis at 415 nm and CE-ESI-TOF/MS results to be 0.20 and 0.45g/dL for plasma respectively.<ref name="staub1"/>
===Detection of cobalt concentration by utilizing the biokinetic model===
Co can be detected by laboratory blood analysis if the intake amount is greater than 400 μg per day. As the whole blood concentration is greater than 1 μg/L and the urinary concentration is greater than 10 μg/L after at least 10 days of administration. The dose, which increases the red blood cell production to approximately 16%-21%, is about 68 mg Co per day for at least 10 days of oral administration. The predicted whole blood concentration of cobalt exceeds 200 μg/L two hours after the last intake and the average urine concentrations of cobalt exceed 3000 μg/L within 24 hours of intake. A study was carried out where 23 subjects were to take 900 μg per day in the form of CoCl<sub>2</sub> for 10 days. The model predictions were then compared to the study. The result shows that the model prediction for blood and urine are between the median concentration of the male and female groups, which indicate the model predictions sufficiently represent the test population as a whole.<ref name="legett1">{{cite journal | last1 = Legett | first1 = R. W. | year = | title = The Biokenetic of Inorganic Cobalt in the Human Body | url = | journal = Science of the Total Environment | volume = 2008 | issue = | pages = 259–269 }}</ref>
==Military use== As early as 1947, military research scientists were studying ways to increase [[fighter pilot]]s’ tolerance for hypoxia at high altitude. In one such study, red blood cells were transfused into ten males at the US Naval Research facility, resulting in increased oxygen capacity.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pace |title=The increase in hypoxia tolerance of normal men accompanying the polycythemia induced by transfusion of erythrocytes. |journal=The American Journal of Physiology |date=January 1947}}</ref>
In 1993, U.S. [[Special Forces]] commanders at [[Fort Bragg, North Carolina|Fort Bragg]] started experimenting with blood doping, also known as blood loading. Special Forces operators would provide two units of whole blood, from which red blood cells would be extracted, concentrated, and stored under cold temperatures. 24 hours before a mission or battle, a small amount of red blood cells would be infused back into the soldier. Military scientists believe that the procedure increases the soldiers’s endurance and alertness because of the increase in the blood's capability to carry oxygen.
In 1998, the Australian Defence Forces approved this technique for the Special Air Service Regiment. Senior nutritionist at the Australian Defence Science and Technology Organization Chris Forbes-Ewan is quoted as saying that, unlike in sport, "all's fair in love and war." "What we are trying to gain is an advantage over any potential adversary," Forbes-Ewan said.<ref>Russell, Ken (1998-09-18). [http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v98.n812.a06.html Australia: Troops Get The All-Clear To Dose Up On Energy Drugs]. ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]].'' Retrieved on 2011-06-01.</ref> In this study, over 50 performance-enhancing drugs and techniques were rejected. The six that were approved are [[caffeine]], [[ephedrine]], [[energy drinks]], [[modafinil]], [[creatine supplements|creatine]], and blood-loading.<ref>{{cite book |last= Pugliese |first=David |title= Canada's Secret Commandos |isbn= 978-1-895896-18-3 |year= 2002 |publisher= Esprit de Corps Books |location= Ottawa}}</ref>
==Notable blood doping cases== [[File:RIAN archive 585168 5,000m race.jpg|thumb|Kaarlo Maaninka (208), the subject of the first known blood doping case, in the 1980 Summer Olympics 5,000 m race.]] Blood doping started in the late 1960s but was not outlawed until 1986.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://library.la84.org/SportsLibrary/ISS/ISS2401/ISS2401e.pdf|title=History of Doping in Sport|last=|first=|date=2002|website=|publisher=International Sports Studies, Vol 24, Issue 1|access-date=October 26, 2016}}</ref> While it was still legal, it was commonly used by middle and long-distance runners. The first known case of blood doping occurred at the [[1980 Summer Olympics]] in Moscow as [[Kaarlo Maaninka]] was transfused with two pints of blood before winning medals in the 5 and 10 kilometer track races, though this was not against the rules at the time.<ref name="Sytkowski2006">{{cite book|author=Arthur J. Sytkowski|title=Erythropoietin: Blood, Brain and Beyond|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v135CsEL_LQC&pg=PA187|accessdate=19 July 2012|date=May 2006|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-3-527-60543-9|pages=187–}}</ref> Cyclist [[Joop Zoetemelk]] admitted to receiving blood transfusions during the [[1976 Tour de France]], where he finished second, although he claimed that these were intended to treat his anaemia rather than enhance his performance.<ref name=cn /> The American cyclist [[Patrick McDonough (cyclist)|Pat McDonough]] admitted to blood doping at the [[1984 Summer Olympics]] in Los Angeles.<ref name="Kayne2006">{{cite book|author=Steven B. Kayne|title=Sport And Exercise Medicine For Pharmacists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X_MlPlBSS20C&pg=PA232|accessdate=19 July 2012|year=2006|publisher=Pharmaceutical Press|isbn=978-0-85369-600-1|pages=232–}}</ref> Following the 1984 Summer games it was revealed that one-third of the U.S. cycling team had received blood transfusions before the games, where they won nine medals, their first medal success since the [[1912 Summer Olympics]].<ref name="Kayne2006"/> In the same year cyclist [[Francesco Moser]] used blood transfusions to prepare for his successful attempt to break the [[hour record]].<ref name=cn>{{cite web |url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/features/a-history-on-the-use-of-blood-transfusions-in-cycling |title=A history on the use of blood transfusions in cycling |last1=McKay |first1=Fergal|date=22 March 2015 |website=[[cyclingnews.com]] |access-date=22 March 2015}}</ref> "Blood doping" was banned by the IOC in 1985, though no test existed for it at the time.<ref name="Kayne2006"/>
The Swedish cyclist [[Niklas Axelsson]] tested positive for EPO in 2000.
The American cyclist [[Tyler Hamilton]] failed a fluorescent-activated cell sorting test for detecting homologous blood transfusions during the [[2004 Olympics]]. He was allowed to keep his gold medal because the processing of his sample precluded conducting a second, confirmatory test. He appealed a second positive test for homologous transfusion from the 2004 [[Vuelta a España]] to the International [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] but his appeal was denied. Hamilton's lawyers proposed Hamilton may be a genetic [[chimera (genetics)|chimera]] or have had a '[[vanishing twin]]' to explain the presence of red blood cells from more than one person. While theoretically possible, these explanations were ruled to be of "negligible probability".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/news.php?id=features/2005/hamilton_decision | title = The Hamilton decision | date = April 19, 2005 | publisher = [[Future Publishing]] | website = Cyclingnews.com | accessdate = 2007-07-30 }}</ref>
The Spanish-based [[Operación Puerto doping case|Operación Puerto case]] in 2006 involved allegations of doping and blood doping of hundreds of athletes from Spain, Germany, Italy, Colombia, Australia, Luxembourg, The Netherlands and The USA.
[[Tour de France]] rider [[Alexander Vinokourov]], of the [[Astana Team]], tested positive for two different blood cell populations and thus for homologous transfusion, according to various news reports on July 24, 2007. Vinokourov was tested after his victory in the 13th stage time trial of the Tour on July 21, 2007. A doping test is not considered to be positive until a second sample is tested to confirm the first. Vinokourov's B sample has now tested positive, and he faces a possible suspension of 2 years and a fine equal to one year's salary.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/Sport/Vinokourov-questions-French-lab-findings/2007/07/29/1185647716109.html| title = Vinokourov questions French lab findings | date = July 29, 2007 | publisher = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | accessdate = July 29, 2007 }}</ref> He also tested positive after stage 15.<ref>"Vinokourov Fails Tour Doping Test." ''BBC News''<nowiki>. BBC, 24 July 2007. Web. 07 Oct. 2015. <http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/cycling/6914301.stm>.</nowiki></ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cyclingpost.com/tour/article_005163.shtml | title = Vinokourov also found positive on Monday | publisher = Cyclingpost.com | accessdate = July 29, 2007 }}</ref>
Vinokourov's teammate Andrej Kashechkin also tested positive for homologous blood doping<ref>{{cite web | url = http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/news.php?id=news/2007/aug07/aug09news | title = Kashechkin tests positive for blood doping | publisher = Cyclingnews.com | accessdate = August 9, 2007 }}</ref> on August 1, 2007, just a few days after the conclusion of the [[2007 Tour de France]] (a race that had been [[Doping at the 2007 Tour de France|dominated by doping scandals]]). His team withdrew after the revelation that Vinokourov had doped.
According to Russian investigators, 19-year-old [[New York Rangers]] prospect and Russian hockey player [[Alexei Cherepanov]] was engaged in blood doping for several months before he died on October 13, 2008, after collapsing on the bench during a game in Russia. He also had [[myocarditis]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=261215 |title= Russian investigators say Cherepanov was 'doping' |date= December 29, 2008 |publisher= [[The Sports Network|TSN]] |agency= [[Canadian Press]] |accessdate= December 29, 2008 }}</ref>
The German speed skater and five-fold Olympic gold medalist [[Claudia Pechstein]] was banned for two years in 2009 for alleged blood doping, based on irregular levels of [[reticulocyte]]s in her blood and the assumption that these levels were always highest during competitions. Her mean reticulocyte count over the ten years from 2000 to 2009 was 2.1% during top events like Olympic Games and during world championships. At world cup races the mean reticulocyte was 1.9% and during training phases 2.0%.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Gassmann | first1 = W | year = 2010 | title = Analysis of erythrocytic blood counts of speed skater Claudia Pechstein | url = | journal = German J Sports Med | volume = 61 | issue = | pages = 227–235 }}</ref> The [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] confirmed the ban in November 2009 in stating: "...once the possibility of a blood disease has been safely excluded...".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/sport/233/495558/text/|title=Sportgericht urteilt gegen Pechstein|date=25 November 2009|website=sueddeutsche.de|postscript=<!--None-->|language=de}}</ref> In September 2010, the Swiss Federal Supreme Court rejected the athlete's appeal, stating that Pechstein's inherited blood anomaly had been known before ("die vererbte Blutanomalie bekannt gewesen sei").<ref>"Bundesgericht weist Revisionsgesuch der Eisschnellläuferin Claudia Pechstein ab", Medienmitteilung des Bundesgerichts, 1 October 2010. (German)</ref>
On May 20, 2011 [[Tyler Hamilton]] turned in his 2004 Olympic Gold Medal to the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency <ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-20/cyclist-tyler-hamilton-hands-in-2004-olympic-gold-medal-to-doping-agency.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Eben | last=Novy-Williams | title=Cyclist Tyler Hamilton Hands in 2004 Olympic Gold Medal to Doping Agency | date=May 20, 2011}}</ref> after admitting to doping in a ''[[60 Minutes]]'' interview.
On August 23, 2012 [[Lance Armstrong]] was stripped of his seven Tour de France titles and banned for life by cycling's governing body following a report from the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency that accused him of leading a doping program during his cycling career. He later admitted to using banned substances including blood doping with transfusions and EPO in an interview with [[Oprah Winfrey]] on January 17, 2013.<ref>Karlinsky, Neal. "Lance Armstrong Stripped of 7 Tour De France Titles, Banned for Life After Doping Scandal." ''ABC News''<nowiki>. ABC News Network, 22 Oct. 2012. Web. 06 Oct. 2015. <http://abcnews.go.com/US/lance-armstrong-stripped-tour-de-france-titles-banned/story?id=17535635>.</nowiki></ref>
In June 2014, UFC fighter [[Chael Sonnen]] tested positive for EPO.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2124293-chael-sonnen-admits-use-of-hgh-epo-in-response-to-nsac-complaint|title=Chael Sonnen Admits Use of HGH, EPO in Response to NSAC Complaint|first=Steven|last=Rondina|publisher=}}</ref> One month later, another UFC fighter, [[Ali Bagautinov]] also tested positive for EPO.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mmajunkie.com/2014/07/bcac-ali-bagautinov-tests-positive-for-epo-for-ufc-174-suspended-one-year|title=BCAC: Ali Bagautinov tests positive for EPO for UFC 174, suspended one year|date=10 July 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
In December 2017, Russia was banned from the 2018 Winter Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea due to systematic doping among Russian Olympians.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/05/sports/olympics/ioc-russia-winter-olympics.html?smid=tw-nytimes&smtyp=cur&_r=0</ref>
==Adverse effects== The simple act of increasing the number of red blood cells in blood may be associated with hyperviscosity syndrome which is characterized by increased blood viscosity and decreased cardiac output and blood flow velocity which results in the reduction of peripheral oxygen delivery.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Smith | first1 = DA | last2 = Perry | first2 = PJ | year = 1992 | title = The efficacy of ergogenic agents in athletic competition. Part II: Other performance-enhancing agents | doi = 10.1177/106002809202600510 | pmid = 1591427 | journal = Ann Pharmacother | volume = 26 | issue = 5| pages = 653–659 }}</ref> For instance, an overdose of EPO can thicken blood into a highly viscous and artery-clogging sludge. This increases the chances of heart attack, stroke, [[phlebitis]], and [[pulmonary embolism]], which has been seen in cases where there is too much blood reintroduced into the blood stream. Because blood doping increases the volume of red blood cells, it effectively introduces a condition called [[polycythemia]], a blood disorder that has known adverse outcomes such as heart attacks or strokes.
Blood contamination during preparation or storage is another issue. Contamination was seen in 1 in every 500,000 transfusions of red blood cells in 2002.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Blajchman | first1 = M | year = | title = Incidence and significance of the bacterial contamination of blood components | url = | journal = Dev Biol (Basel) | volume = 108 | issue = | pages = 59–67 }}</ref> Blood contamination can lead to [[septicemia]] or an infection that affects the whole body.
Certain medications used to increase red blood cells can reduce liver function and lead to liver failure, pituitary problems, and increases in cholesterol levels.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Urhausen | first1 = Axel | last2 = Torsten | first2 = Albers | last3 = Wilfried | first3 = Kindermann | year = 2003 | title = Reversibility of the effects on blood cells, lipids, liver function and hormones in former anabolic–androgenic steroid abuser | url = | journal = The Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology | volume = 84 | issue = 2–3| pages = 369–375 | doi=10.1016/s0960-0760(03)00105-5}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Use British English|date=February 2015}} {{more footnotes|date=March 2008}} '''Britain's Man''' is an annual strongman event held in the [[United Kingdom]]. Competitors qualify for the final through regional heats and the winner is awarded the title of "Britain's Strongest Man".[https://web.archive.org/web/20080421175323/http://www.theworldsstrongestman.com/wsm/bsm/qualifiers.html?neq Retrieved from archive.org showing qualifiers] The competition is produced by [[Trans World International|TWI]] and serves as a qualifying event for the [[World's Strongest Man]] ("WSM") competition, also a TWI production. ==History== {{See also|Strength Athletics in the United Kingdom and Ireland}} In a history that has close parallels with that of the [[World's Strongest Man]] competition, the BSM competition has had a number of sponsors and, at different times, has had to vie with rival competitions that also claim to produce the strongest man in Britain as their champion. The inaugural competition was in 1979David Webster, Sons of Samson Volume 2 Profiles, page 78 (Ironmind Enterprises), {{ISBN|0-926888-06-4}} and was organised by TWI. It was covered by the [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]]. The final contest involved the [[field athletes]] [[Geoff Capes]] and [[Jim Whitehead (hammer thrower)|Jim Whitehead]], weightlifter [[Andy Drzewiecki]], powerlifter [[Ray Nobile]], Highland Games specialists [[Bill Anderson (Highland games)|Bill Anderson]] and [[Grant Anderson (Highland games)|Grant Anderson]], wrestler [[Pat Roach|Big Pat Roach]], and [[Tosher Killingback]]; it was won by [[Geoff Capes]].[http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/title/156049 BFI film and tv database] The contestants were there by invitation. The format continued until 1984. There was then a break of three years, from 1985 through 1988, before the competition returned in 1989. In 1986, there was a ''"[[Britain's Most Powerful Man]]"'' and, in 1988, a competition was organised by [[Geoff Capes]] and [[David Webster (World's Strongest Man organizer)|David Webster]] to find a successor to Geoff Capes, called the John Smith's Trial of Strength. The results of these competitions are often deemed to be equivalent to Britain's Strongest Man given the lack of a competition in those years. The [[International Federation of Strength Athletes|IFSA]], after its creation in the mid-nineties, managed the event but parted company with TW1 after the completion of the 2004 event. TW1 have managed to have the event televised since the BBC opted out in 2004, with [[Sky One]] covering it in 2005, and [[Five (TV channel)|Five]] in 2007 and 2008. The competition is currently sponsored by [[Met-Rx]]. As of 2017, Channel 5 currently broadcasts an episode devoted to the Britain's Strongest Man contest as part of its annual World's Strongest Man coverage in late December.[https://www.my5.tv/worlds-strongest-man-2017/season-38/episode-2] ==Events== Events for the competition include tyre flips, chain drags, Atlas stones and keg tossing.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080726061307/http://www.theworldsstrongestman.com/wsm/bsm/index.html List of events] ==Rival and parallel competitions== *In 2005 the 'IFSA Strongman British Championship' (or ''"British Championships (IFSA)"'') was held in direct competition with the BSM. However, this was short lived, lasting just one year, with the more established BSM gaining better sponsorship (from [[Met-Rx]]) and television coverage ([[Sky One]]) largely due to its longevity, its qualifying status for [[World's Strongest Man]] and also its perception amongst the strongman community as the chief competition. The winner of this breakaway competition, [[Mark Felix]], has since put his energies into competing in the BSM. *A more enduring rival competition is the [[UK Strongest Man]] 'Ultimate Strength Challenge', which began in 1992 and still continues today. However, competing in the BSM and the UKSC is not mutually exclusive and competitors are free to compete in both. This event is run by the UKSC - the UK Strength Council, and focuses more on pure strength rather than strength and speed. *Other rival or parallel competitions that should not be confused with the BSM are: **"''[[UK Championship (IFSA)]]''", which only ran for one year in 1997 **"''[[Britain's Most Powerful Man]]''", which, although a "rival" in 2007, was last run in 1986, when there was no BSM and its winners are counted in the same list as the winners of the BSM **"''[[British Muscle Power Championship]]''" - this ran from 1986 to 1998 and included some of the biggest names of British strength athletics, including [[Geoff Capes]], [[Jamie Reeves]], [[Mark Higgins (athlete)|Mark Higgins]], [[Forbes Cowan]], [[Gary Taylor (strongman)|Gary Taylor]] and [[Russ Bradley]]. However, it was not so much a rival of BSM as an extra competition. == List of champions == {| class="wikitable" !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Year !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Champion [[Shropshire]] |- |1983 || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Geoff Capes]] || {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Jack Hynd]] ||{{flagicon|WAL}} [[John Burns (strongman)|John Burns]] ||[[Nottingham]] |- |1982 || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Richard Slaney]] || {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Hamish Davidson]] ||{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Andy Drzewiecki]] & {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Errol Carnegie]] & {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Peter Welch (strongman)|Peter Welch]] ||[[Brighton]], [[Sussex]] |- |1981 || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Geoff Capes]] || {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Hamish Davidson]] || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Richard Slaney]] ||London |- |1980 || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Richard Slaney]] || {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Jack Hynd]] || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Steve Zetolofsky]] ||[[London]], South Bank |- |1979 || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Geoff Capes]] || {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Bill Anderson (Highland games)|Bill Anderson]] || {{flagicon|ENG}} [[Jim Whitehead (hammer thrower)|Jim Whitehead]] ||Woking Leisure Centre, [[Woking]] |} ===Notes=== # Jimmy Marku was formerly of {{flag|Albania}}. # Mark Felix was formerly of {{flag|Grenada}}. # ''"Britain's Most Powerful Man "'' was the name of the competition in 1986 # Several competitors from other European countries took part. ==Clash of the Giants== In 2011, an event was organised in [[Boroughbridge]] advertised to allow spectators to see "top British strongmen compete to take a step closer towards a place at World's Strongest Man". The event was organised by multiple World's Strongest Man entrant [[Darren Sadler]] and the top two places, won by [[Rob Frampton]] and [[Jack McIntosh (strongman)|Jack McIntosh]], received invitations to North Carolina to compete at the 32nd World's Strongest Man. Clash of the Giants was designed to fill the void left by the absence of the Britain's Strongest Man competition last held in 2008, much as the 1988 John Smith's Trial of Strength had been created following the discontinuation of the BSM in 1984. Unlike the BSM, which is the final stage of a knockout competition comprising a number of regional and national rounds, the Clash of the Giants was a singular event. Because there was no regional tiered competition preceding, it there was no prerequisite that the Clash of the Giants have a field of athletes representing each area of Britain and notably all the athletes competing were English. In addition, the three most successful British strength athletes actively competing at the time, namely [[Terry Hollands|Hollands]], [[Mark Felix|Felix]] and [[Laurence Shahlaei|Shahlaei]], had qualified for the WSM via international grand prix events and did not compete. == Championships by country == {| class="wikitable" !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Country !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Titles |- |{{ENG}} || 25 |- | {{NIR}} || 4 |- |{{SCO}} || 2 |- |{{WAL}} || 2 |- |} == Repeat champions == {| class="wikitable" !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Champion !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Times |- |{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Eddie Hall]] || 5 |- |{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Jamie Reeves]] || 4 |- |{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Geoff Capes]] || 3 |- |{{flagicon|NIR}} [[Glenn Ross]] || 3 |- |{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Richard Slaney]] || 2 |- |{{flagicon|WAL}} [[Gary Taylor (strongman)|Gary Taylor]] || 2 |- |{{flagicon|SCO}} [[Forbes Cowan]] || 2 |- |{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Rich Gosling]] || 2 |- |{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Laurence Shahlaei]] || 2 |} ==See also== *[[List of Strongman Competitions]] ==References== *[http://www.davidhorne-gripmaster.com/strongmanresults.html David Horne's World of Grip] is the source of the names and placings of the above finalists and champions. ==Notes== {{reflist}} [[Category:Strongmen competitions]] [[Category:Competitions in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1979 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1979]] [[Category:Annual events in the United Kingdom]]

الشباب الرياضي لبلدية بن باديس | nickname = ''les cartesiennes'' | founded = {{Start date and years ago|1936|01|01}}
as ''Descartes Football Club'' | ground = [[Stade 1 novembre]], [[Ben Badis, Sid Bel Abbés]] | capacity = 8,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = taib benchinoun | manager = | league = [[Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur]] | season = [[2017-18 Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur|2017–18]] | position = Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur, Group West '''5th''' | current = 2018–19 CRB Ben Badis season | website = http://www.crbbb.blogspot.com/ |pattern_la2=_redborder |pattern_b2=_thinredsides |pattern_ra2=_redborder |leftarm2=FF0000 |body2=FF0000 |rightarm2=FF0000 |shorts2=FFFFFF |socks2=FF0000 |pattern_la1=_greenborder |pattern_b1=_thingreensides |pattern_ra1=_greenborder |leftarm1=008000 |body1=008000 |rightarm1=008000 |shorts1=FFFFFF |socks1=FFFFFF || }} '''Chabab Reyadi Baladiyat Ben Badis''' ({{lang-ar|الشباب الرياضي لبلدية بن باديس}}), known as '''CRB Ben Badis''' or '''CRBBB''' for short, is an [[Algeria]]n football club based in [[Ben Badis, Sid Bel Abbés]]. The club was founded in 1936 and its colors are green, red and white. Their home stadium, the [[1 november Stadium]], has a capacity of some 8,000 spectators. The club is currently playing in the [[Ligue Nationale du Football Amateur]]. == History == ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090515014439/http://www.lnf.org.dz/d1/oma.htm LNF Profile] {{Algerian Championnat National 2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ben Badis, CRB}} [[Category:Football clubs in Algeria]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1946]] [[Category:Oran Province]] [[Category:1946 establishments in Algeria]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Algeria]] {{Algeria-footyclub-stub}}

{{for|the award for the [[American Hockey League]] playoff champion|Calder Cup}} {{Infobox sports award | name = Calder Memorial Trophy | current_event = | image = Hhof calder.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | sport = [[Ice hockey]] | givenfor = [[Rookie of the Year (award)|Rookie of the Year]] in the [[National Hockey League]] | first = [[1936–37 NHL season]] | last = | mostrecent = [[Mathew Barzal]]
[[New York Islanders]]}} The '''Calder Memorial Trophy''' is an annual [[National Hockey League awards|award]] given "to the player selected as the most proficient in his first year of competition in the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL)." It is named after [[Frank Calder]], the [[NHL Commissioner#NHL Presidents/Commissioners|first president]] of the NHL. Serving as the NHL's [[Rookie of the Year (award)|Rookie of the Year]] award, this version of the trophy has been awarded since its creation for the [[1936–37 NHL season]]. The voting is conducted by members of the [[Professional Hockey Writers' Association]] at the conclusion of each [[season (sports)|regular season]] to determine the winner. == History== [[File:Red Dutton, 1944.jpg|thumb|left|200px|NHL president [[Red Dutton]] presenting the Calder Memorial Trophy to [[Gus Bodnar]] in 1944]] The Calder Memorial Trophy is named in honour of [[Frank Calder]], the former President of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) from its inception in 1917 to his death in 1943. Although ''Rookie of the Year'' honors were handed out beginning in [[1932–33 NHL season|1932–33]], the Calder Trophy was first presented at the conclusion of the [[1936–37 NHL season]].{{cite web|url=http://www.legendsofhockey.net/html/silver_splashcalder.htm |title=Silverware: Calder Memorial Trophy |accessdate=August 21, 2007 |work=Legends Of Hockey |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930005454/http://www.legendsofhockey.net/html/silver_splashcalder.htm |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df= }} After Calder's death in 1943 the trophy was renamed the Calder Memorial Trophy.{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/page.htm?id=24931|title=Calder Memorial Trophy|accessdate=August 21, 2007|work=[[National Hockey League]]}} In [[1989–90 NHL season|1990]], [[Sergei Makarov (ice hockey)|Sergei Makarov]] of the [[Calgary Flames]] became the oldest player, at age 31, to win the trophy, even though he had played for [[HC CSKA Moscow]] (the "Red Army" team) in the [[Soviet Union]].{{cite web|url=http://www.legendsofhockey.net/LegendsOfHockey/jsp/SilverwareTrophyWinner.jsp?tro=CMT&year=1989-90|title=Sergei Makarov|accessdate=August 21, 2007|work=Legends Of Hockey}} After that season, the rules for awarding the Calder were amended so that players could only be eligible if they were younger than 27 years old by September 15 of their rookie season. To be eligible for the award, a player cannot have played any more than 25 regular season games previously in any single season, nor have played in more than six regular season games in each of two separate preceding seasons in ''any'' major professional league. The latter fact was perhaps most prominent when in the [[1979–80 NHL season|1979–80]] season, first-year phenom [[Wayne Gretzky]] was not eligible to win the Calder Trophy despite scoring 137 points (the previous rookie record at the time being 95), because he had played a full season the previous year in the [[World Hockey Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oilersheritage.com/history/big_players_waynegretzky.html|title=Wayne Gretzky-The Great One|accessdate=August 21, 2007|work=Oilers Heritage|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416014532/http://www.oilersheritage.com/history/big_players_waynegretzky.html|archivedate=April 16, 2007|df=}} In [[1990–91 NHL season|1991]], goaltender [[Ed Belfour]] won the Calder having previously appeared in 32 games with the [[Chicago Blackhawks]] over the [[1988–89 NHL season|1988–89]] and [[1989–90 NHL season|1989–90]] seasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/pdisplay.php?pid=295|title=Ed Belfour hockey statistics and profile|work=Internet Hockey Database|accessdate=February 8, 2015}} Belfour was eligible for the award because nine of those appearances came during the [[1990 Stanley Cup playoffs]], and the other 23 appearances were made during the 1988-89 season. The nine playoff games did not count towards the regular season eligibility requirements. In [[2010–11 NHL season|2010–11]], [[Logan Couture]] was eligible for the Calder Trophy despite having played in 40 previous games (25 in the regular season and 15 in the playoffs, both in [[2009–10 NHL season|2009–10]]), while [[Alex Pietrangelo]] was ineligible despite having played only 17 previous games (eight in [[2008–09 NHL season|2008–09]] and nine in 2009–10, both times sent back to juniors). The trophy has been won the most times by rookies from the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]], who have won it on ten occasions, with the most recent being [[Auston Matthews]] in 2017. The voting is conducted at the end of the regular season by members of the [[Professional Hockey Writers' Association]], and each individual voter ranks their top five candidates on a 10–7–5–3–1 points system.{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/inside_game/jon_dolezar/news/2003/04/01/dolie_insider/|title=Foppa shows the most Hart|accessdate=August 17, 2007|date=April 20, 2003|last=Dolezar|first=Jon|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]}} Three finalists are named and the trophy is awarded at the NHL Awards ceremony after the playoffs. ==Winners == [[File:Howie Meeker Calder.jpg|right|200px|thumb|[[Howie Meeker]], winner in 1947]] [[File:Terry Sawchuk 1963.JPG|right|200px|thumb|[[Terry Sawchuk]], winner in 1951]] [[File:Eric vail atlanta flames 1978.jpg|right|200px|thumb|[[Eric Vail]], winner in 1975]] [[File:Mario Lemieux 2001.jpg|right|200px|thumb|[[Mario Lemieux]], winner in 1985]] [[File:Pavel Bure in Canucks uniform.jpg|right|200px|thumb|[[Pavel Bure]], winner in 1992]] [[File:Daniel Alfredsson.jpg|200px|thumb|[[Daniel Alfredsson]], winner in 1996]] [[File:Alexander Ovechkin 1 2016-03-01.JPG|right|200px|thumb|[[Alexander Ovechkin]], winner in 2006]] [[File:Gabriel Landeskog in 2012 cropped.jpg|right|200px|thumb|[[Gabriel Landeskog]], winner in 2012]] {| class="wikitable" |+Positions key ! {{Infobox baseball team | Name = Cebu Dolphins| Founded = 2007 | League = [[Baseball Philippines]] | Location = [[Cebu]], [[Manila]] | Stadium = [[Rizal Memorial Sports Complex|Rizal Memorial Baseball Stadium]] | Colors = [[Teal (color)|Teal]] | LeagueChamps = 1| h_cap=ADD8E6| h_pattern_cap=| h_leftarm=ADD8E6| h_pattern_la=| h_body=ADD8E6| h_pattern_b=_baseball| h_rightarm=ADD8E6| h_pattern_ra=| h_pants=FFFFFF| h_pattern_pants=_beltonwhite| h_socks=FFFFFF| a_cap=ADD8E6| a_pattern_cap=| a_leftarm=ADD8E6| a_pattern_la=| a_body=ADD8E6| a_pattern_b=_baseball| a_rightarm=ADD8E6| a_pattern_ra=| a_pants=FFFFFF| a_pattern_pants=_beltonwhite| a_socks=FFFFFF| }} The '''Cebu Dolphins''' are a baseball team in the [[Baseball Philippines]] formed in 2007 as one of its charter members. Owned by Industrial Enterprises and assigned in the league's South Division, the Dolphins won their first championship during the league's Series 2. Along with four national team members, the team is composed mostly of past and present players from the [[De La Salle Green Archers]] in the [[UAAP]] and a few coming from the Cebu province. The team is coached by DLSU and national softball team coach Isaac Bacarisas. Cebu was among the top teams in Series 1 by posting a clean 4-0 elimination round slate only to lose to eventual champion [[Makati Mariners]] in the semis and then to the [[Manila Sharks]] for third place. The Dolphins, however, recovered in Series 2 by posting a seven-win, three-loss card after the elimination before ousting Dumaguete for the division title. They then went on to defeat the Sharks in a grueling three-game matchup which saw an impressive pitching effort by Joseph Orillana. ==Roster== * Angeles, Ruben, Infielder, RP Team * Angeles, Kristoper, Infielder, DLSU * Alquiros, Marco, Infielder, DLSU * Ardio, Jeffrey, Pitcher/Utility, DLSU * Atilano, Emerson, Infielder * Bacarisas, Jerome, Infielder/Pitcher, RTU * Baroque, Gabby, First Baseman/Outfielder, DLSU * Baroque, Miguel, Catcher, DLSU * Binarao, Joel, Infielder * Corcuera, Miggy, First Baseman, DLSU * Dela Cerna, JR, Utility * De Juras, Sofronio * De Ubago, Jon, Outfielder * [[Richard Gomez|Gomez, Richard]], Outfielder * Olaybar, Anthony, Infielder * Omandac, Saxon, Infielder/Pitcher * Orillana, Joseph, Pitcher, Utility, RP Team * Orobia, Jordan * Palacol, Roswald * Ponce, Jonash, Centerfielder, RP Team * Rances, Fulgencio, Catcher, RP Team * Seung Jun, Ha, Pitcher/Infielder, PCU * Uichico, Nico, Utility, DLSU * [[Ervic Vijandre|Vijandre, Ervic]], Utility, DLSU ==Tournament Results== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#efefef" !Tournament !W !L !PCT !Playoffs |- |2007 Series One |4 |0 |1.000 |Lost 5-4 in semis vs Makati
Lost 5-3 vs Manila for third place |- |2007 Series Two |7 |3 |.700 |Won 7-6 in Division Championship vs Dumaguete
Beat Manila in the Championship Series, 2 games to 1 |- |'''Total''' |11 |3 |.786 |- |} ==External links== * [http://www.baseballphilippines.com/CebuDolphinsClubhouse.htm Baseball Philippines Official Site: Cebu Dolphins] {{Baseball Philippines}} [[Category:Sports clubs established in 2007]] [[Category:Baseball Philippines]] [[Category:Baseball teams in the Philippines]] [[Category:Sports in Cebu]] [[Category:2007 establishments in the Philippines]] {{Philippines-sport-stub}} {{asia-baseball-team-stub}}

{{coord|27.956994|-82.791499|display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Clearwater Athletic Field | nickname = | image = Clearwater Athletic Field.png | image_size = 250px | fullname = | location = Pennsylvania Ave and Seminole St, Clearwater, Florida | coordinates = | broke_ground = December 1922 | built = | opened = March 15, 1923 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1954 | demolished = 1956 | owner = City of Clearwater | operator = | surface = grass | construction_cost = $25,000 | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = Brooklyn Field | tenants = [[Brooklyn Dodgers]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (spring training) ([[1923 Brooklyn Robins season|1923]]–[[1932 Brooklyn Dodgers season|1932]]; [[1936 Brooklyn Dodgers season|1936]]–[[1941 Brooklyn Dodgers season|1941]])
Clearwater Pelicans ([[Florida State League|FSL]]) (1924)
[[Newark Bears (International League)|Newark Bears]] ([[International League|IL]]) (spring training) (1933–1935)
[[Cleveland Indians]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (spring training) ([[1942 Cleveland Indians season|1942]] and [[1946 Cleveland Indians season|1946]])
Clearwater Bombers ([[Amateur Softball Association|ASA]]) (1945–1954)
[[Philadelphia Phillies]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]) (spring training) ([[1947 Philadelphia Phillies season|1947]]–[[1954 Philadelphia Phillies season|1954]])
Clearwater Black Sox (FSNBL) (1952) | seating_capacity = 3,000 | dimensions = Left – 340 ft.
Center – ft.
Right – 290 ft. }} '''Clearwater Athletic Field''' was a [[stadium]] in [[Clearwater, Florida]]. It was first used by professional baseball teams for spring training in 1923 and was the Phillies' first spring training ballpark in Clearwater. The grandstand sat approximately 2,000 and bleachers increased capacity to close to 3,000. Home plate was located on Pennsylvania Avenue, which ran south to north along the third base line, near Seminole Street. Left field ran parallel to Palmetto Street, and right field ran parallel to Greenwood Ave. The grandstand was destroyed by fire in April 1956.{{cite news |title=Clearwater Fire Destroys Grandstand|author= |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=X-chAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6GQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3613,2043786&dq=clearwater+athletic+field&hl=en|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |date=1956-04-14|accessdate=2011-03-14|page=13}} The North Greenwood Recreation and Aquatic Complex now stands on the site of ballpark. On March 19, 2016, the site of the ballpark was recognized as a Florida Heritage Site and the location added to the state's heritage map.{{cite news |first=Sherri|last=Landgon|title=Clearwater Athletic Field Earns Historic Designation |url=https://patch.com/florida/clearwater/clearwater-athletic-field-earns-historic-designation-0|work=Clearwater Patch |date=March 15, 2016|accessdate=2018-03-25|page=}} ==History== In October 1922, the Brooklyn Dodgers agreed to train in Clearwater in 1923 provided the city would clear a field and construct grandstands. The Clearwater city council voted to issue $25,000 in bonds for construction. The Dodgers' move to Florida brought the number of major league clubs conducting spring training in the state to seven.{{cite news |title=Big Leaguers Seek Grounds |author= |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KhFPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=v0wDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5916,799742&dq=clearwater+dodgers&hl=en|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times |date=1922-10-22|accessdate=2011-03-15|page=7}} The first game was played on March 15, 1923 between the Dodgers and the [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]], who trained in St. Petersburg. The game was preceded by a parade to the park and Commissioner [[Kenesaw Mountain Landis]] threw out the first pitch to Clearwater mayor Frank J. Booth.{{cite news |title=Braves to Meet Dodgers in Clearwater Thursday|author= |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sMULAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kVQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2289,5158179&dq=clearwater+dodgers&hl=en|newspaper=St. Petersburg Evening Independent |date=1923-03-12|accessdate=2011-03-15|page=14}} More than 4,000 fans saw the Dodgers defeat the Braves 12-7.{{cite news |title=Dodgers Win From Boston|author= |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sQlPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=B00DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6585,2045513&dq=clearwater+dodgers&hl=en|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times |date=1923-03-16|accessdate=2011-03-15|page=6}} It was the spring training home of the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]], [[Newark Bears (International League)|Newark Bears]] (when the top [[minor league baseball]] teams held their own spring training), [[Cleveland Indians|Cleveland]], and the [[Philadelphia Phillies]]. The [[Florida State League]]'s Clearwater Pelicans{{cite book |title=Spring Training in Clearwater: Fencebusters and Fastballs from the Philadelphia Philles and the Clearwater Threshers|last=De Quesada |first=Alejandro M. |authorlink= |author2=Larry Shenk |year=2007 |publisher=The History Press |location= |isbn=1-59629-214-8 |page=24 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1gzZsGw2bP8C&pg=PA24&dq=%22Clearwater+Pelicans%22&client=firefox-a#PPA24,M1 |accessdate=}} and the [[Amateur Softball Association]] national-champion Clearwater Bombers played their home games at Athletic Field.{{cite news | first=Lester R.| last=Dailey | title=Bombers put Clearwater on the map: The home-grown softball team won 10 national championships| date=2008-02-20| work=Clearwater Citizen | url =http://www.tbnweekly.com/content_articles/022008_cit-05.txt| pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-19 | language = }} The Florida State Negro Baseball League Clearwater Black Sox played at the park in 1952.{{cite news | first=E. H.| last=McLin | title=Pelicans face Ocala in League Opener Sunday| date=1952-04-29| work=[[St. Petersburg Times]] | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TEILAAAAIBAJ&sjid=H08DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4088,6471944&dq=clearwater+pelicans| pages =24| accessdate = 2009-03-22 | language = }} ==Phillies in Clearwater== Cleveland was sold in June 1946 to [[Bill Veeck]] and a note soon appeared in the ''Sporting News'' that the team was considering a spring training move to [[Hi Corbett Field|Tucson, Arizona]] for 1947. Paul Ficht, secretary of the Clearwater Chamber of Commerce, along with Mayor J.C. House, and City Manager F.L. Hendrix spoke with the [[History of the St. Louis Browns|St. Louis Browns]], Newark Bears, [[Kansas City Blues (American Association)|Kansas City Blues]], and Phillies about training in Clearwater in 1947. On July 27, 1946, Hendrix announced that the Phillies had accepted Clearwater's invitation to train at Athletic Field in 1947 on a one-year agreement. On March 7, 1947, the Phillies and city signed a 10-year deal for the Phillies to train in Clearwater. The Phillies lost their first spring training game in 1947 at Athletic Field to the Detroit Tigers by a score of 13-1. The Phillies' attendance that spring was 13,291 which was ninth out of the ten teams training in Florida.{{cite magazine |last=Lewis |first=Allen|date=March 1986 |title=Philadelphia '47 '86 Clearwater|url= |magazine=1986 Phillies: Spring Training 40th Year in Clearwater|location=Clearwater, Florida |publisher=Philadelphia Phillies|access-date=|pages=4-5 }} One of the largest crowds for a spring training game was on March 24, 1951, when the Phillies drew 3,851 against the [[1951 Boston Red Sox season|Boston Red Sox]].{{cite news | first=| last= | title=Phillies Beat Red Sox; Goliat Clouts Homer| date=1951-03-25| newspaper=Reading Eagle| url =| page=Section 4, page 27}} ==After 1955== It was replaced in 1955 by [[Jack Russell Memorial Stadium|Jack Russell Stadium]], into which both the Phillies and Bombers moved after the 1954 season. Even after moving into Jack Russell in 1955, the Phillies continued to practice at the field.{{cite news | first=| last= | title=Boston Pitchers Wild, Ineffective| date=1955-03-17| newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-tcbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0GQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4124,3582106&dq=phillies&hl=en|page =13}} Fire destroyed the grandstand in 1956 but the field remained in use. The [[Baltimore Orioles]] team in the Winter Instructional League trained at Athletic Field in October 1959 and played their home games next door at Jack Russell Stadium.{{cite news | first=| last= | title=Winter League Orioles Open Workouts Today| date=1959-10-08| newspaper=St. Petersburg Times | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19591008&id=BfINAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BHcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4887,3570919| work = | page =5-C| accessdate = 2009-05-01 | language = }} At the time of the fire which destroyed the grandstands on April 12, 1956, it was reported that city managers planned to tear down the grandstands in 1957 and replace them with temporary bleachers.{{cite news |title=Wind-Whipped Blaze Levels Stands, Home |author=Al Hackett |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uD1SAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BHYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7137,6249601&dq=clearwater+athletic+field&hl=en|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=1956-04-12|accessdate=2011-03-14}} Ray Green Field was also used for parking for games at Jack Russell Stadium.{{cite news | first=Kaylois| last=Henry| title=Clearwater gets go-ahead on parking spaces, stadium| date=1989-09-17 | newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/50550567.html?FMT=FT&dids=50550567:50550567&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+17%2C+1989&author=KAYLOIS+HENRY&pub=St.+Petersburg+Times&desc=Clearwater+gets+go-ahead+on+parking+spaces%2C+stadium| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-19 | language = }} The North Greenwood Recreation and Aquatic Complex now stands on the site of the ballpark. In 2003, the city opened the Ray E. Green Aquatic Center, named in honor of the mayor.{{cite news | first=Sharon| last=Kennedy Wynne | title=Metro Week in Review: Coming up this week| date=2003-04-13| newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]] | url =http://www.sptimes.com/2003/04/13/TampaBay/Teachers_get_richer_p.shtml| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-03-19 | language = }} In February 2018, football team [[D.C. United]] trained in Clearwater and used the grass fields at Walter C. Campbell Park between the recreation center and [[Jack Russell Memorial Stadium]].{{cite news | first=Steven| last=Goff| title=With Yamil Asad deal almost done, D.C. United sorts through midfield options| date=February 5, 2018|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/soccer-insider/wp/2018/02/05/with-yamil-asad-deal-almost-done-d-c-united-sorts-through-midfield-options/| work = Washington Post| pages = | accessdate = 2008-03-25 | language = }} ==Name== The ballpark is often identified as "Clearwater Athletic Field" or "Clearwater's Athletic Field". It was renamed Ray Green Field in honor of Ray Green, mayor of Clearwater from 1935 to 1938,{{cite web|url=http://www.clearwater-fl.com/gov/city_council/faq.asp|title=Mayor & City Council: Frequently Asked Questions|accessdate=2009-03-19|work=|publisher=My Clearwater.com: The Official Website of the City of Clearwater, Florida|date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302194132/http://www.clearwater-fl.com/gov/city_council/faq.asp|archivedate=2009-03-02|df=}} who was instrumental in upgrading the facility during his tenure as mayor.{{cite news | first=Lois V.| last=Arnold| title=A stadium conjures up memories| date=1993-08-17| publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]]| url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=C_UNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f3sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6928,1649424&dq=green+field+clearwater| work = | pages =2| accessdate = 2009-03-20 | language = }} In a 1980 interview, Eddie Moore, director of Clearwater parks and recreation from 1938 to 1978, recalled that the ballpark was called "Brooklyn Field" during the Dodgers' tenure.{{cite news | first=Tommy| last=Kouzmanoff| title=Jack Russell Stadium Has Continued To Be Of Benefit To Clearwater| date=1980-03-16 | newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XQMMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JFoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5606,1085199&dq=phillies| work = | page =4 | accessdate = 2009-09-18 | language = }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} A 1939 news article recounts the Clearwater Senior Softball League playing at "Brooklyn field".{{cite news | first=| last=| title=Senior Leaguers to Resume Play at County Seat| date=1939-08-14 | newspaper=The Evening Independent|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nHoLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=p1QDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4407,3562660&dq=brooklyn-field|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120723112051/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nHoLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=p1QDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4407,3562660&dq=brooklyn-field|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-07-23| work = | page =11 | accessdate = 2009-09-21| language = }} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://www.digitalballparks.com/Grapefruit/Green.html Digital Ballparks: Green Field]
