A '''golf course superintendent''' is a person who professionally manages the labor, time, materials and financial resources needed to care for the [[turfgrass]] and landscaped grounds on a [[golf course]]. Golf course superintendents have also been referred to as [[greenskeeper]]s and turf managers. Golf course superintendents are concerned with the environmental health of the golf course, the sporting needs of the players and the financial sustainability of the golf club or [[country club]] for which they work. Golf course superintendents communicate the status of the grounds and maintenance resources to members of the club’s management, owners or [[board of directors]], green chairs and committees, golfers, vendors, suppliers, golf professionals, golf course architects and others in the golf industry. Their management strategies must also align with the golf club business’ environmental and philanthropic role in the community. Golf course superintendents carefully monitor the natural weather patterns, environment and other influences that affect the playing areas and landscapes with which golfers interact. Golf course superintendents monitor the health of the golf course environment through careful study, diagnosis and treatment of disease and injury to the golf course’s turfgrass fairways, tees and greens areas, as well as bunkers, areas of [[water hazard]], naturalized areas and trees. Their skilled management of the course is accomplished through a detailed knowledge of biology, chemistry, [[plant pathology]] and [[entomology]]. Golf course superintendents can be officially certified by the [[Golf Course Superintendents Association of America]] '''(GCSAA)'''. ==Certified Golf Course Superintendent== A Certified Golf Course Superintendent is one that has voluntarily met the requirements set forth by the GCSAA to receive the professional distinction of a CGCS. The requirements to qualify for eligibility into the certification program vary depending on years of education, focus of the education, continuing education credits received, and the number of years as a class "A” Superintendent. Once eligible, one must complete a portfolio of work samples, case studies, and skill statements. This portfolio must be completed and approved by two existing Certified Superintendents. In addition to the completed portfolio, a rigorous closed book exam must be passed. Finally, the superintendents current facility must be inspected, evaluated, and "passed" by two current Certified Superintendents. Once certified, superintendents must partake in a required amount of education classes and service activities as well as uphold a code of ethics, specific to those of the CGCS distinction. == Job responsibilities == {{see also|Turf management#Golf courses|Greenskeeper|Equipment manager}} Golf course superintendents skillfully maintain a course’s [[turfgrass]], which is considered to be a manufactured product because it is specifically planted, raised and maintained to provide players with a surface on which to play golf. There is a science-based process behind the turfgrass they produce which involves various steps and stages throughout the year. The average golf course superintendent makes between $70–80,000 a year. On more prestigious courses they can make over $150,000 a year. As of the year 2010, there were superintendents making over $400,000 a year, some of whom got that salary directly and others considering benefits such as, but not limited to: free house, free vehicle, free gasoline and holiday bonuses. == External links == * [http://www.gcsaa.org/ GCSAA] * [http://www.gcsane.org/golf/ GCSANE] * [http://www.turfgrasssod.org/ Turfgrass Producers of America] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040515154305/http://www.usga.org/home/index.html USGA] * [http://www.magcs.org/ MAGCS] == Sources == {{nofootnotes|date=August 2009}} 1. Golf Course Superintendents Association of America. [http://www.GCSAA.org]
2. United States Golf Association. [http://www.usga.org/turf/green_section_record/2006/nov_dec/so_you_want.html] * [http://www.usga.org/turf/green_section_record/2006/jul_aug/thebest.html] * [http://www.usga.org/turf/articles/management/committees/communicate.html] 3. North Carolina State University Turf Files Glossary. [http://www.turffiles.ncsu.edu/Glossary.aspx]
4. The North Carolina Agricultural Extension Service, INSECT and other PESTS associated with TURF. [http://ipm.ncsu.edu/AG268/html/contents.html]
5. New England Greenkeepr. [http://newenglandgreenkeeper.com/Documents/DCPCJobdescriptions.pdf] 6. Rocky Mountain GCSA. [http://www.rmgcsa.org] {{DEFAULTSORT:Golf Course Superintendent}} [[Category:Golf clubs and courses]] [[Category:Golf people]] [[Category:Sports occupations and roles]]

{{Use British English|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} [[File:Gray's inn zz.JPG|thumb|alt= A grassy foreground, with a tall tree and shrubs, with a terrace of red brick buildings in the background and left side|<center>'''Gray's Inn Square, London WC1'''</center>|300px]] '''The Honourable Society of Gray's Inn''', commonly known as '''Gray's Inn''', is one of the four [[Inns of Court]] (professional associations for [[barrister]]s and judges) in London. To be [[called to the bar]] and practise as a barrister in [[England and Wales]], a person must belong to one of these Inns. Located at the intersection of [[High Holborn]] and [[Gray's Inn Road]] in [[Central London]], the Inn is both a [[professional body]] and a provider of office accommodation ([[chambers (law)|chambers]]) for many barristers. It is ruled by a governing council called "Pension", made up of the Masters of the Bench (or "[[Bencher]]s"), and led by the [[Treasurer#In the Inns of Court|Treasurer]], who is elected to serve a one-year term. The Inn is known for its gardens, or Walks, which have existed since at least 1597.
Gray's Inn does not claim a specific foundation date; there is a tradition that none of the Inns of Court claims to be any older than the others. [[Law clerk]]s and their apprentices have been established on the present site since at least 1370, with records dating from 1381. During the 15th and 16th centuries, the Inn grew steadily with great prestige, reaching its pinnacle during the reign of [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]]. The Inn was home to many important barristers and politicians, most notably [[Francis Bacon]], and counted Elizabeth herself as a patron. Thanks to the efforts of prominent members such as [[William Cecil, 1st Baron Burghley|William Cecil]] and [[Gilbert Gerard (judge)|Gilbert Gerard]], Gray's Inn became the largest of the four by number, with over 200 barristers recorded as members. During this period, the Inn became noted for the masques and revels that it threw, and [[William Shakespeare]] is believed to have first performed ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'' there.
The Inn continued to prosper during the reign of [[James I of England|James I]] (1603–1625) and the beginning of that of [[Charles I of England|Charles I]], when over 100 students per year were recorded as joining. The outbreak of the [[First English Civil War]] in 1642 during the reign of Charles I disrupted the systems of legal education and governance at the Inns of Court, shutting down all calls to the Bar and new admissions, and Gray's Inn never fully recovered. Fortunes continued to decline after the [[English Restoration]], which saw the end of the traditional method of legal education. Although now more prosperous, Gray's Inn is today the smallest of the Inns of Court. [[File:COA 1st Baron Grey of Wilton.svg|thumb|150px|alt= Shield shape showing alternating blue and silver horizontal stripes|[[Coat of Arms|Arms]] of the [[Baron Grey de Wilton|Barons Grey de Wilton]], founding 14c owners of Gray's Inn]]
==Role== {{See also|Barristers in England and Wales|Inns of Court}} Gray's Inn and the other three Inns of Court remain the only bodies legally allowed to [[call to the Bar|call]] a [[barrister]] to the Bar, allowing him or her to practise in England and Wales.<ref name="ginna">{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=section&id=1&Itemid=659|title=Gray's Inn – About Us|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref> Although the Inn was previously a disciplinary and teaching body, these functions are now shared between the four Inns, with the [[Bar Standards Board]] (a division of the [[General Council of the Bar]]) acting as a disciplinary body and the Inns of Court and Bar Educational Trust providing education. The Inn remains a collegiate self-governing, unincorporated association of its members, providing within its precincts library, dining, residential and office accommodation ([[chambers (law)|chambers]]), along with a chapel. Members of the Bar from other Inns may use these facilities to some extent.<ref name="estate"/><ref name=hs/>
==History== During the 12th and early 13th centuries, the law was taught in the [[City of London]], primarily by the clergy. Then two events happened which ended the Church's role in legal education: firstly, a [[papal bull]] that prohibited the clergy from teaching the [[common law]], rather than [[canon law]];<ref name=watt1>Watt (1928) p. 133</ref><ref>Bellot (1902) p. 32</ref> and secondly, a decree by [[Henry III of England]] on 2 December 1234 that no institutes of legal education could exist in the City of London.<ref>Douthwaite (1886) p.2</ref> The common law began to be practiced and taught by laymen instead of clerics, and these lawyers migrated to the hamlet of [[Holborn]], just outside the City and near to the law courts at [[Westminster Hall]].<ref name=watt1/>
[[File:St Giles & Holborn Civil Parish Map 1870.png|thumb|250px|left|A map showing the boundaries of the Inn in 1870]]
===Founding and early years=== The early records of all four [[Inns of Court]] have been lost, and it is not known precisely when each was founded. The records of Gray's Inn itself are lost until 1569, and the precise date of founding cannot therefore be verified.<ref>Simpson (1973) p. 132</ref> [[Lincoln's Inn]] has the earliest surviving records. Gray's Inn dates from at least 1370,<ref>Watt (1928) p. 139</ref> and takes its name from [[Reginald de Grey, 1st Baron Grey de Wilton|Baron Grey of Wilton]], as the Inn was originally Wilton's family [[Townhouse (Great Britain)|townhouse]] (or inn) within the Manor of Portpoole.<ref name=dou1>Douthwaite (1886) p. 3</ref> A lease was taken for various parts of the inn by practising lawyers as both residential and working accommodation, and their apprentices were housed with them. From this the tradition of dining in "commons", probably by using the inn's main hall, followed as the most convenient arrangement for the members. Outside records from 1437 show that Gray's Inn was occupied by ''socii'', or members of a society, at that date.<ref name=dou1/>
In 1456 Reginald de Gray, the owner of the Manor itself, sold the land to a group including [[Thomas Bryan (Chief Justice)|Thomas Bryan]]. A few months later, the other members signed deeds of release, granting the property solely to Thomas Bryan.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xx</ref> Bryan acted as either a [[feoffee]] or an owner representing the governing body of the Inn (there are some records suggesting he may have been a [[Bencher]] at this point) but in 1493 he transferred the ownership by charter to a group including [[Robert Brudenell (Chief Justice)|Sir Robert Brudenell]] and Thomas Wodeward, reverting the ownership of the Inn partially back to the Gray family.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xxi</ref>
In 1506 the Inn was sold by the Gray family to [[Hugh Denys of Osterley|Hugh Denys]]<ref>Fletcher (1901) p.xxiii</ref> and a group of his feoffees including [[Roger Lupton]].<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xxiii–xxiv</ref> This was not a purchase on behalf of the society and after a five-year delay, it was transferred under the will of Denys in 1516 to the [[Carthusian]] House of Jesus of Bethlehem ([[Sheen Priory]]),<ref>Williams, E. (1906) pp.42–43.</ref> which remained the Society's landlord until 1539,<ref>Pearce (1848) p. 317</ref> when the [[Second Act of Dissolution]] led to the [[Dissolution of the Monasteries]] and passed ownership of the Inn to the Crown.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xxviii</ref>
===Elizabethan golden age=== [[File:Darnley stage 3.jpg|thumb|200px|alt= Woman, facing left, with a tiara on red-coloured hair, wearing voluminous and heavily decorated clothing with large sleeves, tight waist and a ruff round the neck. A crown on a table is visible in the background|[[Elizabeth I of England]], who served as the Inn's patron during its "golden age".]]
During the reign of [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]], Gray's Inn rose in prominence, and that period is considered the "golden age" of the Inn, with Elizabeth serving as the Patron Lady.<ref name="ginn"/> This can be traced to the actions of [[Nicholas Bacon (courtier)|Nicholas Bacon]], [[William Cecil, 1st Baron Burghley|William Cecil]] and [[Gilbert Gerard (judge)|Gilbert Gerard]], all prominent members of the Inn and confidantes of Elizabeth.<ref>Watt (1928) p. 177</ref> Cecil and Bacon in particular took pains to find the most promising young men and get them to join the Inn.<ref>Watt (1928) p. 179</ref> In 1574 it was the largest of all the Inns of Court by number, with 120 [[barrister]]s, and by 1619 it had a membership of more than 200 barristers.<ref name=fletcherxxxii>Fletcher (1901) p. xxxii</ref>
Gray's Inn, as well as the other Inns of Court, became noted for the parties and festivals it hosted. Students performed [[masque]]s and plays in court weddings, in front of Queen Elizabeth herself, and hosted regular festivals and banquets at [[Candlemas]], [[Halloween|All Hallows Eve]] and Easter.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xxxix</ref> At Christmas the students ruled the Inn for the day, appointing a [[Lord of Misrule]] called the ''Prince of Purpoole'',<ref name=coe>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Wlh6609SVJEC&pg=PA1 |title=The Comedy of Errors |chapter=Introduction |author=Charles Whitworth |year=2002 |isbn=978-0-19-281461-6 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> and organising a masque entirely on their own, with the Benchers and other senior members away for the holiday.<ref>Aikenhead (1977) p. 248</ref>
The Gray's Inn masque in 1588 with its centrepiece, ''[[The Misfortunes of Arthur]]'' by [[Thomas Hughes (dramatist)|Thomas Hughes]], is considered by [[Adolphus William Ward|A.W. Ward]] to be the most impressive masque thrown at any of the Inns.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ward|first=A.W.|title=The Cambridge History of English Literature, Volume 5|publisher=BiblioBazaar, LLC|year=2009|page=86|isbn=1-113-14362-2}}</ref> [[William Shakespeare]] performed at the Inn at least once, as his patron, [[Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton|Lord Southampton]], was a member.<ref name=last>{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=category&sectionid=1&id=1&Itemid=661|title=Gray's Inn – History|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=24 August 2009}}</ref> For the Christmas of 1594, his play ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]'' was performed by the [[Lord Chamberlain's Men]] before a riotous assembly of notables in such disorder that the affair became known as the ''Night of Errors'' and a mock trial was held to arraign the culprit.<ref name=coe/>
Central to Gray's was the system shared across the Inns of Court of progress towards a [[call to the Bar]], which lasted approximately 12 to 14 years. A student would first study at either [[Oxford]] or [[Cambridge University]], or at one of the [[Inns of Chancery]], which were dedicated legal training institutions.<ref>Watt (1928) p. 9</ref> If he studied at Oxford or Cambridge he would spend three years working towards a degree, and be admitted to one of the Inns of Court after graduation. If he studied at one of the Inns of Chancery he would do so for one year before seeking admission to the Inn of Court to which his Inn of Chancery was tied—in the case of Gray's Inn, the attached Inns of Chancery were [[Staple Inn]] and [[Barnard's Inn]].<ref>Steel (1907) p. 586</ref>
The student was then considered an "inner barrister", and would study in private, take part in the [[moot court|moots]] and listen to the readings and other lectures. After serving from six to nine years as an "inner barrister," the student was called to the Bar, assuming he had fulfilled the requirements of having argued twice at moots in one of the Inns of Chancery, twice in the Hall of his Inn of Court and twice in the Inn Library.<ref name=fletcherxxxiii>Fletcher (1901) p. xxxiii</ref> The new "utter barrister" was then expected to supervise bolts ("arguments" over a single point of law between students and barristers)<ref>Spilsbury (1850) p. 19</ref> and moots at his Inn of Court, attend lectures at the Inns of Court and Chancery and teach students. After five years as an "utter" barrister he was allowed to practice in court—after 10 years he was made an Ancient.<ref name=fletcherxxxiii/>
The period saw the establishment of a regular system of legal education. In the early days of the Inn, the quality of legal education had been poor—readings were given infrequently, and the standards for call to the Bar were weak and varied. During the Elizabethan age readings were given regularly, moots took place daily and barristers who were called to the Bar were expected to play a part in teaching students, resulting in skilled and knowledgeable graduates from the Inn.<ref name=fletcherxxxii/>
[[File:II Gray's Inn, London, UK 2.jpg|thumb|left|[[Francis Bacon]] House at Gray's Inn]]
Many noted barristers, judges and politicians were members of the Inn during this period, including [[Gilbert Gerard (judge)|Gilbert Gerard]], [[Master of the Rolls]], [[Edmund Pelham]], [[Lord Chief Justice of Ireland]], and [[Francis Bacon]], who served as Treasurer for eight years, supervising significant changes to the facilities of the Inn and the first proper construction of the gardens and walks for which the Inn is noted.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xlii</ref>
===Caroline period and the English Civil War=== [[File:1677 Gray's Inn.jpg|thumb|alt= Old layout of Gray's Inn, showing the buildings, the walks and the surrounding roads|250px|A 1677 map of Gray's Inn at Holborn.]] At the start of the [[Caroline era]], when Charles I came to the throne, the Inn continued to prosper. Over 100 students were admitted to the Inn each year, and except during the plague of 1636 the legal education of students continued.<ref name=fletch12>Fletcher (1901) p. xliii</ref> Masques continued to be held, including one in 1634 organised by all four Inns that cost £21,000—approximately £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|21000|1634|r=-3}}}} in {{CURRENTYEAR}} terms.<ref name=fletch12/> Before 1685 the Inn counted as members five [[duke]]s, three [[Marquess|marquises]], twenty-nine [[earl]]s, five [[viscounts]] and thirty-nine [[baron]]s, and during that period "none can exhibit a more illustrious list of great men".<ref>Edward (1860) p. 99</ref>
Many academics, including [[William Holdsworth]], a man considered to be one of the best legal academics in history,<ref>Campbell (1983) p. 66</ref> maintain that this period saw a decline in the standard of teaching at all the Inns.<ref name=aikenhe1>Aikenhead (1977) p. 249</ref> From 1640 onwards no readings were held, and barristers such as [[Edward Coke|Sir Edward Coke]] remarked at the time that the quality of education at the Inns of Court had decreased.<ref name=aikenhe1/> Holdsworth put this down to three things—the introduction of printed books, the disinclination of students to attend moots and readings and the disinclination of the Benchers and Readers to enforce attendance.<ref>Aikenhead (1977) p. 250</ref>
With the introduction of printing, written legal texts became more available, reducing the need for students to attend readings and lectures. However, this meant that the students denied themselves the opportunity to query what they had learnt or discuss it in greater detail.<ref>Holdsworth (1921) p. 202</ref> Eventually, as students now had a way to learn without attending lectures, they began to excuse themselves from lectures, meetings and moots altogether; in the early 17th century they developed a way of deputising other students to do their moots for them.<ref>Holdsworth (1921) p. 203</ref> The Benchers and Readers did little to arrest the decline of the practice of lecturers and readings, first because many probably believed (as the students did) that books were an adequate substitute, and secondly because many were keen to avoid the work of preparing a reading, which cut into their time as practising barristers.<ref>Holdsworth (1921) p. 204</ref> These problems were endemic to all the Inns, not just Gray's Inn.<ref name=aikenhe1/>
The outbreak of the [[First English Civil War]] led to a complete suspension of legal education, and from November 1642 until July 1644 no Pension meetings were held. Only 43 students were admitted during the four years of the war, and none were called to the Bar.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xliv</ref> Meetings of Pension resumed after the [[Battle of Marston Moor]] but the education system remained dormant. Although Readers were appointed, none read, and no moots were held.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xlv</ref> In 1646, after the end of the war, there was an attempt to restore the old system of readings and moots, and in 1647 an order was made that students were required to moot at least once a day.<ref>Holdsworth (1921) p. 208</ref> This failed to work, with Readers refusing to read, and the old system of legal education completely died out.<ref>Holdsworth (1921) p. 209</ref> [[File:gray's inn zzz.JPG|thumb|250px|alt= A grassy area with floral shrubs and a central statue on a plinth, with terraced buildings in the background|South Square, Gray's Inn WC1.]] The Caroline period saw a decline in prosperity for Gray's Inn.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. li</ref> Although there were many notable members of the Inn, both legal ([[Dudley Digges|Sir Dudley Digges]], [[Thomas Bedingfield (judge)|Thomas Bedingfield]] and [[Francis Bacon (judge)|Francis Bacon]], for example) and non-legal (including [[William Juxon]], the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]]), the list could not compare to that of the Elizabethan period.<ref name=fletcherlii>Fletcher (1901) p. lii</ref> Following the [[English Restoration]], admissions fell to an average of 57 a year.<ref name=fletcherlii/>
===English Restoration to present=== The fortunes of Gray's Inn continued to decline after the [[English Restoration]], and by 1719 only 22 students were joining the Inn a year.<ref name=fletcher2ix>Fletcher (1910) p. ix</ref> This fall in numbers was partly because the landed gentry were no longer sending sons who had no intention of becoming barristers to study at the Inn. In 1615, 13 students joined the Inn for every student called to the Bar, but by 1713 the ratio had become 2.3 new members to every 1 call.<ref>Fletcher (1910) p. x</ref>
Over a 50-year period, the Civil War and high taxation under [[William III of England|William III]] economically crippled many members of the gentry, meaning that they could not afford to allow their sons to study at the Inns.<ref name=fletcher2xi>Fletcher (1910) p. xi</ref> David Lemmings considers it to have been more serious than that, for two reasons; firstly, [[Inner Temple]] and [[Middle Temple]] had actually shown an increase in membership following the Restoration, and secondly because Gray's Inn had previously had far more "common" members than the other Inns.<ref name="lem-lem">Lemmings (1990)</ref> The decrease in the number of gentry at the Inn could therefore not completely explain the large drop in members.<ref name="lem-lem"/>
Gray's Inn was the venue for an early [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match]] on Thursday, 2 July 1730 between [[London Cricket Club|London]] and [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]]. Kent won the game by an unknown margin. The original source reports "a cricket-match between the Kentish men and the Londoners for [[Pound sign|£50]], and won by the former", giving the precise location as "a field near the lower end of [[Gray's Inn Road|Gray's Inn Lane, London]]".<ref>Ashley-Cooper, p. 96.</ref><ref>Waghorn, p. 1.</ref><ref>Wilson, p. 44.</ref><ref>Maun, p. 42.</ref><ref>ACS, ''Important Matches'', p. 19.</ref>
In 1733 the requirements for a call to the Bar were significantly revised in a joint meeting between the Benchers of Inner Temple and Gray's Inn, revisions accepted by Lincoln's Inn and Middle Temple, although they were not represented.<ref>Fletcher (1910) p. xxiii</ref> It is not recorded what these changes were, but after a further discussion in 1762 the Inns adopted a rule that any student with a Master of Arts or [[Bachelor of Laws]] degree from the universities of [[Oxford]] or [[Cambridge]] could be called to the Bar after three years as a student, and any other student could be called after five years.<ref name=fletcher2xxiv>Fletcher (1910) p. xxiv</ref> An attempt was made to increase the quality of legal education at Gray's Inn; in 1753 a barrister, [[Danby Pickering]], was employed to lecture there, although this agreement ended in 1761 when he was called to the Bar.<ref name=fletcher2xxiv/>
The 18th century was not a particularly prosperous time for the Inn or its members, and few notable barristers were members during this period. Some noted members include [[Thomas Clarke (jurist)|Sir Thomas Clarke]], the [[Master of the Rolls]], [[James Eyre (judge)|Sir James Eyre]], [[Chief Justice of the Common Pleas]] and [[Samuel Romilly]], a noted law reformer.<ref>Fletcher (1910) p. xxxi</ref> In 1780 the Inn was involved in the case of ''R v the Benchers of Gray's Inn'', a test of the role of the Inns of Court as the sole authority to call students to the Bar. The case was brought to the [[Court of King's Bench (England)|Court of King's Bench]] by William Hart, a student at the Inn, who asked the court (under [[Lord Mansfield]]) to order the Inn to call him to the Bar. Mansfield ruled that the Inns of Court were indeed the only organisations able to call students to the Bar, and refused to order the Inns to call Hart.<ref>Watt (1928) p. 25</ref>
During the 19th century, the Inns began to stagnate; little had been changed since the 17th century in terms of legal education or practice, except that students were no longer bound to take the [[Church of England|Anglican]] [[sacrament]] before their [[call to the Bar]].<ref name=last/> In 1852 the [[Council of Legal Education]] was established by the Inns, and in 1872 a formal examination for the [[call to the Bar]] was introduced.<ref name=last/> Gray's Inn itself suffered more than most; as in the 18th century, the fortunes of its members declined, and many barristers who had been [[called to the Bar]] at the Inn transferred to others.<ref>Ruda (2008) p. 108</ref>
Gray's Inn was the smallest of the Inns during the early 20th century, and was noted for its connection to the [[Northern Circuit]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Camp|first=William|title=The Glittering Prizes – A Biographical Study of F. E. Smith, First Earl of Birkenhead|publisher=Macgibbon & Kee|location=London|year=1960|oclc=2323156|page=28}}</ref> During the [[Second World War]], the Inn was badly damaged during [[the Blitz]] in 1941, with the Hall, the Chapel, the Library and many other buildings hit and almost destroyed. The rebuilding of much of the Inn took until 1960<ref name="estate"/> by the architect Sir [[Edward Maufe]].<ref>Graysinn.info accessed September 2011</ref> In 2008 Gray's Inn became the first Inn to appoint "fellows"—elected businesspeople, legal academics and others—with the intent of giving them a wider perspective and education than the other Inns would offer.<ref name="tdt">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/lawreports/joshuarozenberg/3226544/Some-jolly-good-fellows.html|title=Some jolly good fellows|last=Rozenberg|first=Joshua|date=19 October 2008|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref>
==Structure and governance== Gray's Inn's internal records date from 1569, at which point there were four types of member; those who had not yet been [[called to the Bar]], Utter Barristers, Ancients and Readers.<ref>Simpson (1973) p. 134</ref> Utter Barristers were those who had been called to the Bar but were still studying, Ancients were those who were called to the Bar and were allowed to practise and Readers were those who had been called to the Bar, were allowed to practise and now played a part in educating law students at the [[Inns of Chancery]] and at Gray's Inn itself. At the time Gray's Inn was the odd one out amongst the Inns; the others did not recognise Ancients as a degree of barrister and had Benchers roughly corresponding to the Readers used at Gray's Inn (although the positions were not identical).<ref name=simpson135>Simpson (1973) p. 135</ref>
The Inn is run by Pension, its ultimate governing body. The name is peculiar to Gray's Inn—at [[Lincoln's Inn]] the governing body is called the Council, and at the [[Inner Temple|Inner]] and [[Middle Temple]]s it is called the Parliament. The name was used for the governing bodies of three of the Inns of Chancery—[[Barnard's Inn]], [[Clement's Inn]] and [[New Inn (Inn of Chancery)|New Inn]].<ref name=simpson138/> In Gray's Inn the Readers, when they existed, were required to attend Pension meetings, and other barristers were at one point welcome to, although only the Readers would be allowed to speak. Pension at Gray's Inn is made up of the Masters of the Bench, and the Inn as a whole is headed by the Treasurer, a senior Bencher. The Treasurer has always been elected, and since 1744 the office has rotated between individuals, with a term of one year.<ref name=fletcher2xxiv/>
===Readers=== A [[Reader (Inns of Court)|Reader]] was a person literally elected to read—he would be elected to the Pension (council) of Gray's Inn, and would take his place by giving a "reading", or lecture, on a particular legal topic.<ref name=simpson138/> Two readers would be elected annually by Pension to serve a one-year term. Initially (before the rise of the Benchers) the Readers were the governing body of Gray's Inn, and formed Pension.<ref name=simpson139/> The earliest certain records of Readers are from the 16th century—although the Inn's records only start at 1569 [[William Dugdale]] (himself a member) published a list in his ''Origines Juridiciales'' dating from 1514. S.E. Thorne published a list dating from 1430, but this is entirely conjectural and not based on any official records, only reports of "readings" that took place at Gray's Inn.<ref name=simpson135/> By 1569 there had certainly been Readers for more than a century.<ref name=simpson138>Simpson (1973) p. 138</ref>
The [[English Civil War]] marked the end of legal education at the Inns, and the class of Readers went into decline. The last Readers were appointed in 1677, and the position of the Readers as heads of the Inn and members of Pension was taken by the Benchers.<ref name=simpson141/>
===Benchers=== {{see also|Bencher}} A Bencher, Benchsitter or (formally) Master of the Bench,<ref name="tdt"/> is a member of Pension, the governing body of the Honourable Society of Gray's Inn. The term originally referred to one who sat on the benches in the main hall of the Inn which were used for dining and during moots, and the term originally had no significance.<ref name=simpson139>Simpson (1973) p. 139</ref> The position of Bencher developed during the 16th century when the Readers, for unknown reasons, decided that some barristers who were not Readers should be afforded the same rights and privileges as those who were, although without a voice in Pension. This was a rare practice and occurred a total of seven times within the 16th century, the first being Robert Flynt in 1549.<ref name=simpson140/> The next was [[Nicholas Bacon (courtier)|Nicholas Bacon]] in 1550, then [[Edward Stanhope (disambiguation)|Edward Stanhope]] in 1580, who was afforded the privilege because, although a skilled attorney, an illness meant he could never fulfil the duties of a Reader.<ref name=simpson140>Simpson (1973) p. 140</ref>
The practice became more common during the 17th century—11 people were made Benchers between 1600 and 1630—and in 1614 one of the Benchers appointed was explicitly allowed to be a member of Pension.<ref name=simpson141>Simpson (1973) p. 141</ref> This became more common, creating a two-rank system in which both Readers and Benchers were members of Pension. However far more Readers were appointed than Benchers—50 between 1600 and 1630—and it appeared that Readers would remain the higher rank despite this change.<ref name=simpson141/>
The [[English Civil War]] marked the end of legal education at the Inns, although the [[Commonwealth of England|government]] attempted to persuade Readers to continue by threatening them with fines. The class of Readers went into decline and Benchers were called as members of Pension instead.<ref name=simpson141/> In 1679 there was the first mass-call of Benchers (22 on one occasion, and 15 on another),<ref name=simpson141/> with the Benchers paying a fine of 100 marks because they refused to read, and modern Benchers pay a "fine" in a continuation of this tradition.<ref name=simpson142>Simpson (1973) p. 142</ref>
Noted Benchers of Gray's Inn include [[F. E. Smith, 1st Earl of Birkenhead|Lord Birkenhead]] and [[Francis Bacon]].<ref name="ginn">{{cite web|url=http://www.barcouncil.org.uk/about/innsofcourt/graysinn/ |title=Gray's Inn |publisher=Bar Council |accessdate=18 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090803003708/http://www.barcouncil.org.uk/about/innsofcourt/graysinn/ |archivedate=3 August 2009 }}</ref><ref name="wac-bac"/> Honorary Benchers can also be appointed, although they have no role in Pension, such as [[Lord Denning]], who was appointed in 1979,<ref>{{cite book|last=Heward|first=Edmund|title=Lord Denning: A Biography|publisher=George Weidenfeld & Nicolson Limited|year=1990|isbn=0-297-81138-X|page=122}}</ref> and [[Winston Churchill]].<ref name="ginn"/> Today there are over 300 Benchers in Gray's Inn, mostly senior barristers and members of the judiciary.<ref name="gi1">{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=section&id=1&Itemid=659|title=Gray's Inn|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=20 August 2009}}</ref>
===Badge=== [[File:Gray's Inn Griffin (13917927638).jpg|thumb|upright|alt=The Badge depicts a gold griffin on a black background|The Gray's Inn badge (a gold griffin on a black field)]] Gray's Inn does not possess a [[coat of arms]] as such, but instead uses a badge, often displayed on a shield, [[blazon]]ed either "[[Azure (heraldry)|Azure]] an Indian Griffin [[Tincture (heraldry)#Proper|proper]] [[Attitude (heraldry)#Segreant|segreant]]"<ref>Pearce (1848) p. 318</ref> or, more currently, "[[Sable (heraldry)|Sable]] a griffin segreant [[Or (heraldry)|or]]", i.e., a gold [[griffin]] on a black background.<ref name=last/> The Inn originally used a form of the coat of arms of the de Grey family,<ref>Barry of six azure and argent within a bordure quarterly of the second and or: these arms are depicted in the pediment over the Benchers' entrance in South Square</ref> but this was changed at some time around 1600 to the griffin. There is no direct record of why this was done, but it seems likely that the new device was adapted from the arms of the Treasurer Richard Aungier (d. 1597), for two probable reasons: firstly, because he was a particularly important and prestigious member of the Inn, and secondly, because the griffin would have looked more impressive on occasions such as masques and revels than the plain geometric arms of the de Greys.<ref name=last/>
The motto around the badge, the date of adoption of which is unknown, is ''Integra Lex Aequi Custos Rectique Magistra Non Habet Affectus Sed Causas Gubernat'', or "Impartial justice, guardian of equity, mistress of the law, without fear or favour rules men's causes aright".<ref name=last/>
==Buildings and gardens== [[File:Agas Gray's Inn.jpg|thumb|alt= Layout of Gray's Inn, taken from a birds-eye view, showing the Inn as a single walled compound still surrounded by fields.|The Inn's buildings and walks, in a [[Compound (enclosure)|compound]] on the left hand side of "Greys ynne la.", shown on the [[Woodcut map of London|"Woodcut" map of London]] of the 1560s]]
The Inn is located at the intersection of [[High Holborn]] and [[Gray's Inn Road]]. It started as a single [[manor house]] with a hall and chapel, although an additional wing had been added by the date of the [[Woodcut map of London|"Woodcut" map of London]], drawn probably in the early 1560s. Expansion continued over the following decades, and by 1586 the Pension had added another two wings around the central [[Courtyard|court]]. Around these were several sets of [[chambers (law)|chambers]] erected by members of the Inn under a [[leasehold]] agreement whereby ownership of the buildings would revert to the Inn at the end of the lease.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xxxvii</ref>
As the Inn grew it became necessary (for safety purposes) to wall off the land owned by the Inn, which had previously been open to everyone. In 1591 the "back field" was walled off, but little more was done until 1608, when under the supervision of [[Francis Bacon]], the Treasurer, more construction work was undertaken, particularly in walling off and improving the gardens and walks.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xxxviii</ref> In 1629 it was ordered that an architect supervise any construction and ensure that the new buildings were architecturally similar to the old ones, and the strict enforcement of this rule during the 18th century is given as a reason for the uniformity of the buildings at Gray's Inn.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xxlvii</ref>
During the late 17th century many buildings were demolished, either because of poor repair or to standardise and modernise the buildings at the Inn.<ref name=fletcher2ix/> Many more were built over the open land surrounding the Inn, although this was controversial at the time; in November 1672 the [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|Privy Council]] and [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] himself were petitioned to order that nothing should be built on the open land, and a similar request was sent to the [[Lord Chancellor]] in May 1673.<ref name=fletcher2xi/> From 1672 to 1674 additional buildings were constructed in the Red Lyon Fields by [[Nicholas Barbon|Nicholas Barebone]], and members of the Inn attempted to sue him to prevent this. After the lawsuits failed members of the Inn were seen to fight with Barebones' workmen, "wherein several were shrewdly hurt".<ref name=fletcher2xii>Fletcher (1910) p. xii</ref>
In February 1679 a fire broke out on the west side of Coney Court, necessitating the rebuilding of the entire row. Another fire broke out in January 1684 in Coney Court, destroying several buildings including the Library. A third fire in 1687 destroyed a large part of Holborn Court, and when the buildings were rebuilt after these fires they were constructed of brick to be more resistant to fire than the wood and plaster previously used in construction. As a result, the domestic [[Tudor style architecture]] which had dominated much of the Inn was replaced with more modern styles.<ref name=fletcher2xiv>Fletcher (1910) p. xiv</ref> Records show that prior to the rebuilding in 1687, the Inn had been "so incommodious" that the "ancients" were forced to work two to a chamber.<ref>Pulleyn (1830) p. 239</ref> More of the Inn was rebuilt during that period, and between 1669 and 1774 all of the Inn apart from parts of the Hall and Chapel had been rebuilt.<ref name=fletcher2xv/>
More buildings were constructed during the 18th and 19th centuries. In 1941 the Inn suffered under [[The Blitz]], which damaged or destroyed much of the Inn, necessitating the repair of many buildings and the construction of more.<ref name="estate">{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=266&Itemid=848|title=Gray's Inn – The Estate|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=22 August 2009}}</ref> Today many buildings are let as professional offices for barristers and solicitors with between {{convert|265000|sqft}} and {{convert|275000|sqft}} of office space available.<ref name="estate"/> There are also approximately 60 residential apartments, rented out to barristers who are members of the Inn.<ref name=hs>{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=category&sectionid=23&id=139&Itemid=886|title=Gray's Inn – Residential Flats|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=22 August 2009}}</ref> The Inn also contains the [[Inns of Court School of Law]], a joint educational venture between all four Inns of Court where the vocational training for barristers and solicitors is undertaken.<ref>Ruda (2008) p. 117</ref> The current Inn layout consists of two squares—South Square and Gray's Inn Square—with the remaining buildings arranged around the Walks.<ref name=location>{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=section&id=6&Itemid=855 |title=Gray's Inn – Location |publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=21 October 2009}}</ref>
===Hall=== [[File:Gray's Inn Hall 3.jpg|thumb|alt=A large brick rectangular building, with a darker tiled sloping roof; the corners and buttresses of the building have larger white stone blocks as edging, instead of bricks. On the end of the longer side, a porch (approximately half the height of the main building), with four steps leading up to an arch and a large wooden door; above the door, a coat of arms of a golden griffin on a black shield; the wall of the longer side of the building has five brick buttresses, four small high windows and one large oriel window|Gray's Inn Hall, London WC1]] The Hall was part of the original Manor of Portpoole, although it was significantly rebuilt during the reign of [[Mary I of England|Mary I]],<ref name=d113/> and again during the reign of Elizabeth, with the rebuilding being finished on 10 November 1559.<ref>Ireland (1800) p. 175</ref> The rebuilt Hall measured {{convert|70|ft}} in length, {{convert|35|ft}} in width and {{convert|47|ft}} in height, and remains about the same size today.<ref name="hall"/> It has a [[hammerbeam roof]] and a raised dais at one end with a grand table on it, where the Benchers and other notables would originally have sat.<ref>Douthwaite (1886) p. 112</ref>
The hall also contains a large carved screen at one end covering the entrance to the [[Vestibule (architecture)|Vestibule]]. Legend says that the screen was given to the Inn by [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]] while she was the Inn's patron, and is carved out of the wood of a Spanish galleon captured from the [[Spanish Armada]].<ref name="hall">{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=category&sectionid=1&id=1&Itemid=661#anchorhall|title=Gray's Inn – the Hall|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=26 August 2009}}</ref> The Hall was lit with the aid of massive windows filled with the [[Coat of Arms|Coats of Arms]] of those members who became Treasurers.<ref name=d113>Douthwaite (1886) p. 113</ref> The Benchers' table is also said to have been a gift from Elizabeth, and as a result the only public toast in the Inn until the late 19th century was "to the glorious, pious and immortal memory of Queen Elizabeth".<ref>Edward (1860) p. 98</ref>
The walls of the Hall are decorated with paintings of noted patrons or members of the Inn, including [[Nicholas Bacon (courtier)|Nicholas Bacon]] and Elizabeth I.<ref name="Douthwaite 1886 p. 141">Douthwaite (1886) p. 141</ref> During the [[Second World War]] the Hall was one of those buildings badly damaged during [[the Blitz]]. The Treasurers' Arms and paintings had been moved to a place of safety and were not damaged; during the rebuilding after the War they were put back in the Hall, where they remain.<ref name="hall"/> The rebuilt hall was designed by Edward Maufe, and was formally opened in 1951 by the [[Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester|Duke of Gloucester]].<ref>Ruda (2008) p. 115</ref>
===Chapel=== The Chapel existed in the original manor house used by the Inn,<ref name=fletcherxxxv>Fletcher (1901) p. xxxv</ref> and dates from 1315.<ref name="chapel">{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=section&id=3&Itemid=679|title=Gray's Inn – The Chapel|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=22 August 2009}}</ref> In 1625 it was enlarged under the supervision of [[Eubule Thelwall (politician)|Eubule Thelwall]],<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xxlvi</ref> but by 1698 it was "very ruinous", and had to be rebuilt.<ref name=fletcher2ix/> Little is known of the changes, except that the barrister's [[chambers (law)|chambers]] above the Chapel were removed.<ref name=fletcher2xv>Fletcher (1910) p. xv</ref> The building was again rebuilt in 1893, and remained that way until its destruction during [[The Blitz]] in 1941.<ref name="hall"/> The Chapel was finally rebuilt in 1960, and the original stained glass windows (which had been removed and taken to a safe location) were restored.<ref name="hall"/> The rebuilt Chapel contains "simple furnishings" made of Canadian [[maple]] donated by the [[Canadian Bar Association]].<ref>Ruda (2008) p. 104</ref>
The Inn has had a Chaplain since at least 1400, where a court case is recorded as being brought by the "Chaplain of Greyes Inn".<ref>Pearce (1848) p. 316</ref> During the 16th century the Inn began hiring full-time preachers to staff the Chapel—the first, John Cherke, was appointed in 1576.<ref name=fletcherxxxv/> A radical [[Puritan]] in a time of religious conflict, Cherke held his post for only a short time before being replaced by a Thomas Crooke in 1580.<ref name=foster499>Foster (1889) p. 499</ref> After Crooke's death in 1598 Roger Fenton served as preacher, until his replacement by [[Richard Sibbes]], later Master of [[Catherine Hall, Cambridge]], in 1616.<ref name=foster499/> Gray's Inn still employs a Preacher; [[Michael Doe (bishop)|Michael Doe]], former [[Bishop of Swindon]] and more recently General Secretary of the [[USPG|United Society for the Propagation of the Gospel]], was appointed in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=category&sectionid=3&id=155&Itemid=915|title=Gray's Inn – Preacher|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=24 August 2009}}</ref>
===Walks=== [[File:Garden Walks.jpg|thumb|250px|alt=A depiction of the Inn, with special emphasis on the Walks. The rural nature of the surrounding countryside is still evident in the background. | An image from 1702 showing the Walks.]] The Walks are the gardens within Gray's Inn, and have existed since at least 1597, when records show that [[Francis Bacon]] was to be paid £7 for "planting of trees in the walkes".<ref>Douthwaite (1886) p. 183</ref> Prior to this the area (known as Green Court) was used as a place to dump waste and rubble, since at the time the Inn was open to any Londoner.<ref>Jacques (1989) p. 41</ref> In 1587 four Benchers were ordered by the Pension to "consider what charge a brick wall in the fields will draw unto And where the said wall shalbe fittest to be builded", and work on such a wall was completed in 1598, which helped keep out the citizens of London.<ref>Jacques (1989) p. 44</ref>
In 1599 additional trees were planted in the Walks, and stairs up to the Walks were also added.<ref>Jacques (1989) p. 45</ref> When Francis Bacon became treasurer in 1608 more improvements were made, since he no longer had to seek the approval of the Pension to make changes. In September 1608 a gate was installed on the southern wall, and various gardeners were employed to maintain the Walks.<ref>Jacques (1989) p. 46</ref> The gardens became commonly used as a place of relaxation, and [[James Howell]] wrote in 1621 that "I hold [Gray's Inn Walks] to be the pleasantest place about London, and that there you have the choicest society".<ref>Douthwaite (1886) p. 186</ref>
The Walks were well-maintained during the reign of [[William III of England|William III]], although the Inn's lack of prosperity made more improvements impossible.<ref name=fletcher2xxvii/> In 1711 the gardener was ordered not to admit "any women or children into the Walkes", and in 1718 was given permission to physically remove those he found. At the end of the 18th century Charles Lamb said that the Walks were "the best gardens of any of the Inns of Court, their aspect being altogether reverend and law-abiding".<ref name=fletcher2xxvii/> In 1720 the old gate was replaced by "a pair of handsome iron gates with peers and other proper imbellishments".<ref>Jacques (1989) p. 57</ref> The 19th and 20th centuries saw few major changes, apart from the introduction of [[Platanus|plane trees]] into the Walks.<ref>Jacques (1989) p. 58</ref>
The Walks are listed Grade II* on the [[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of special historic interest in England|Register of Historic Parks and Gardens]].<ref name="Gray's Inn">{{NHLE|num=1000351|desc=Gray's Inn|access-date=5 February 2016|mode=cs2}}</ref>
===Library=== The Library of Gray's Inn has existed since at least 1555, when the first mention of it was made in the will of Robert Chaloner, who left some money to buy law books for the Library. The Library was neither a big collection nor a dedicated one; in 1568 it was being housed in a single room in the chambers of [[Nicholas Bacon (courtier)|Nicholas Bacon]], a room that was also used for [[mooting]] and to store the [[deed]] chest. The collection grew larger over the years as individual Benchers such as [[John Finch, 1st Baron Finch|Sir John Finch]] and [[John Bankes|Sir John Bankes]] left books or money to buy books in their wills,<ref>Douthwaite (1886) p. 176</ref> and the first Librarian was appointed in 1646 after members of the Inn had been found stealing books.<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. xlix</ref>
In 1669 books were bought by the Inn as an organisation for the first time,<ref>Fletcher (1901) p. l</ref> and a proper catalogue was drawn up to prevent theft.<ref name="Douthwaite 1886 p. 141"/> In 1684 a fire that broke out in Coney Court, where the Library was situated, and destroyed much of the collection. While some books were saved, most of the records prior to 1684 were lost. A "handsome room" was then built to house the Library.<ref name=fletcher2xiv/>
The Library became more important during the 18th century; prior to that it had been a small, little-used collection of books. In 1725 it was proposed by the Pension that "a publick Library be sett up and kept open for ye use of ye society",<ref name=fletcher2xxvi>Fletcher (1910) p. xxvi</ref> and that more books be purchased. The first order of new books was on 27 June 1729 and consisted of "a collection of [[Francis Bacon|Lord Bacon]]'s works".<ref name=fletcher2xxvi/> In 1750 the Under-Steward of the Inn made a new catalogue of the books, and in 1789 the Library was moved to a new room between the Hall and the Chapel.<ref name=fletcher2xxvii>Fletcher (1910) p. xxvii</ref> In 1840 another two rooms were erected in which to store books, and in 1883 a new Library was constructed with space to store approximately 11,000 books.<ref>Douthwaite (1886) p. 179</ref> This was rapidly found to be inadequate, and in 1929 a new Library, known as the Holker Library after the benefactor, [[John Holker|Sir John Holker]], was opened. The library, although impressive looking, was not particularly useful; Francis Cowper wrote that: <blockquote>Though impressive to look at, the new building was something less than a success as a library. The air of spaciousness was produced at the expense of shelf room, and though in the octagon [at the north end] the decorative effect of row upon row of books soaring upwards towards the cornice was considerable, the loftiest were totally inaccessible save to those who could scale the longest and dizziest ladders. Further, the appointments were of such surpassing mag-nificence that no ink-pots were allowed in the room for fear of accidents.<ref name=ruda1>Ruda (2008) p. 111</ref></blockquote>
The building did not last very long—damage to the Inn during [[the Blitz]] completely destroyed the Library and a large part of its collection, although the rare manuscripts, which had been moved elsewhere, survived. After the destruction of much of the Inn's collection, [[George VI of the United Kingdom|George VI]] donated replacements for many lost texts.<ref>Ruda (2008) p. 106</ref> A prefabricated building in the Walks was used to hold the surviving books while a new Library was constructed, and the new building (designed by [[Edward Maufe|Sir Edward Maufe]]) was opened in 1958.<ref name="lib">{{cite web|url=http://www.graysinn.info/index.php?option=com_content&task=category&sectionid=4&id=9&Itemid=687|title=Gray's Inn – Library|publisher=Gray's Inn|accessdate=26 August 2009}}</ref> It is similar in size to the old Holker Library, but is more workmanlike and designed to allow for easy access to the books.<ref name=ruda1/>
==Notable members== {{main article|List of members of Gray's Inn}} Having existed for over 600 years, Gray's Inn has a long list of notable members and honorary members. Even as the smallest of the [[Inns of Court]] it has had members who have been particularly noted lawyers and judges, such as [[Francis Bacon]],<ref name="wac-bac">{{cite web|url=http://oxforddnb.com/view/article/990?docPos=1|title=Oxford DNB article: Bacon, Francis (subscription needed)|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|first=Markku|last=Peltonen|accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref> [[F. E. Smith, 1st Earl of Birkenhead|The 1st Earl of Birkenhead]], [[Gordon Slynn, Baron Slynn of Hadley|Baron Slynn]], [[Lord Bingham of Cornhill]], [[Lord Hoffmann]] and others. Outside the Bar and judiciary of England and Wales, members have included the clergy (including five [[Archbishop of Canterbury|Archbishops of Canterbury]]),<ref>Douthwaite (1886) p. 195</ref> industrialists like [[John Wynne (industrialist)|John Wynne]], astronomers such as [[John Lee (astronomer)|John Lee]], media figures, like [[Huw Thomas]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/tv-radio-obituaries/5132538/Huw-Thomas.html|title=Huw Thomas – Telegraph|date=9 April 2009|publisher=''The Daily Telegraph''|accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref> and members of the Bar and judiciary of other nations, such as [[Yang Ti-liang|Sir Ti-liang Yang]] (former [[Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Hong Kong]]), [[B. R. Ambedkar]] (principal architect of the Constitution of [[India]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbia.edu/itc/mealac/pritchett/00ambedkar/timeline/1910s.html|title=1910s|first=Frances|last=Pritchett|website=www.columbia.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.open.ac.uk/researchprojects/makingbritain/content/b-r-ambedkar|title=B. R. Ambedkar - Making Britain|website=www.open.ac.uk}}</ref> and also former presidents of [[Cyprus]] [[Spyros Kyprianou]], [[Tassos Papadopoulos]], and [[Glafcos Clerides]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/politics-obituaries/10453574/Glafcos-Clerides-obituary.html|title=Glafcos Clerides – obituary|date=15 November 2013|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=3 April 2015}}</ref>

{{infobox country at games | NPC = GUI | NPCname = Guinea Paralympic Committee | games = Paralympics | year = | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = {{Team appearances list|team=Guinea|competition=Summer Paralympics|begin_year=|end_year= }} | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Guinea]]''' made its [[Paralympic Games]] début at the [[2004 Summer Paralympics]] in [[Athens]], sending a single representative ([[Ahmed Barry]]) to compete in athletics. He took part in two events, and did not win a medal. Barry was, again, Guinea's sole representative at the [[2008 Summer Paralympics]] in Beijing. Entering only one race on that occasion, he was a non-starter. He remains the only person to have represented Guinea at the Paralympic Games.[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=GUI&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Guinea at the Paralympics], [[International Paralympic Committee]] Guinea has never taken part in the Winter Paralympics.[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=GUI&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Guinea at the Paralympics], International Paralympic Committee ==Full results for Guinea at the Paralympics== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Name !Games !Sport !Event !Score !Rank |- | [[Ahmed Barry]] || [[2004 Summer Paralympics|2004 Athens]] || [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Men's 100 m T46 || 13.00 || 7th in heat 2;
did not advance |- | Ahmed Barry || 2004 Athens || Athletics || Men's 200 m T46 || 25.87 || 8th in heat 1;

{{DISPLAYTITLE: ''How to Play Golf''}} '''''How to Play Golf''''' is a 1944 [[short film|short]] animated [[Walt Disney Productions]] film directed by [[Jack Kinney]]. Eight minutes long, it was distributed by [[RKO]], and was a part of a series where [[Goofy]] learned to play various sports. ==Reception== Upon release, ''[[The Film Daily]]'' called it "highly hilarious", and gave the following review:
"This, another of Walt Disney's [[Technicolor]] cartoons featuring the Goof, is a howl. While the narrator explains how properly to play golf, the Goof attempts to demonstrate. Naturally he does everything wrong, with superb results from a comedy point of view. The technique and animation are noteworthy indeed. Mark this down as a topflight booking of its kind."
==See also== *[[List of American films of 1944]] ==References== * "Reviews of the New Films." Film Daily. 5/10/44. p13. ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0036934}} [[Category:Disney animated short films, 1940s]] [[Category:1944 films]] [[Category:1944 animated films]] [[Category:1940s comedy films]] [[Category:1940s sports films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Sports comedy films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Golf animation]] [[Category:Goofy (Disney) short films]] [[Category:Films directed by Jack Kinney]] [[Category:Films produced by Walt Disney]] [[Category:1940s short films]] {{Disney-animation-film-stub}} {{short-comedy-film-stub}} [[Category:Comedy short films]]

[[File:P.I.C.K. 2010.JPG|thumb|Temporary circuit in the streets of [[Patras]]]] A '''kart circuit''' is a [[race track]] designed for [[kart racing]] or other forms of short length motor racing, such as small-scale [[motorcycle racing]], [[pocketbike racing]], or [[Radio-controlled car|radio-controlled model racing]]. There are several types of kart circuit, depending on the type of use desired.
Unlike regular race tracks intended for [[auto racing]] or other forms of [[motorsport]]s, kart circuits are usually much shorter in length, and often consist of numerous turns.
==Circuit types==
===Short circuit=== A short circuit is defined as being an outdoor circuit of less than 1,500 meters in length.
The average length for a serious racing track for karts is around 1,100 - 1,200 meters, 7 to 9 meters in width. Normally custom-built for karting, they resemble road courses, with left and right turns. They generally allow sprint racing for both [[gearbox]] and non-gearbox karts.
Temporary circuits can be set in city streets or large parking lots for special events. This is the case for the [[Junior Monaco Kart Cup]], a prestigious event for young drivers taking place each year in the city of [[Monaco]], and the SKUSA SuperNationals, taking place in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] at the [[Rio All Suite Hotel and Casino]].<ref>[http://www.superkartsusa.com/national/skusa-supernationals.html SKUSA SuperNationals] - SuperKarts! USA</ref>
===Long circuit=== A long circuit is defined as being an outdoor circuit of more than 1,500 m in length.<ref>[http://www.emamc.org.uk/archive/2007/Blue_Book/338-356_Sec_N_-_Karting.pdf Specific Regulations for Karting] - [[Motor Sports Association]] (MSA), Circuits</ref> Typically they are shared for other [[motorsport]] and only have gearbox kart races.
This type of event can see karts ([[Superkart]]) reach speeds in excess of 160 mph (250 km/h).
===Indoor=== [[Image:Indoor karting Florida.jpg|thumb|Indoor track in Florida]] Normally for casual racers, the indoor circuits can be in any closed space (often old [[factory|factories]]), sometimes with a short outdoor section to add interest. Normally they have their own fleet of [[Go-kart]]s or [[micro kart]]s, chosen more for economy than out-and-out speed.
In Europe, indoor karting is where most people will sample their first time in a kart. Indoor karting exploded across the UK in the 1990s and had a similar impact in European countries such as France and Belgium. It has made a lesser impact in the United States. Indoor karting still offers a competitive experience for all levels of racers.
The world longest indoor circuit, the Highway Kart Racing GmbH, 1,600 meters, is located in [[Germany]], [[Dortmund]].<ref>{{De icon}} [http://www.highway-kart-racing.com/index.php?section=bahneninfos Die längste Indoor Kartbahn der Welt] - Highway Kart Racing</ref>
===Others=== In this category fall the dirt-tracks, [[oval]] tracks and [[ice rink]]s.
== Locations == Karting is international and most countries have kart specific racing circuits. Notable{{Ambiguous|date=July 2018}} examples include:
;Latvia * [[Swedbank kartodroms]]
;UK * [[Buckmore Park Kart Circuit]] * [[Daytona Motorsport]] * [[Rye House Kart Circuit]] * [http://www.mansellraceway.com Mansell Raceway Kart Circuit] * [http://www.dunkeswellkartclub.co.uk Dunkeswell Kart Racing Club]
;USA * [[K1 Speed]] * [[Pole Position Raceway]]

English [[intertitles]] | budget = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Kissing Cup''''' is a 1913 British silent [[sports film]] directed by [[ Jack Hulcup]] and starring [[Harry Gilbey]], [[Chrissie White]] and [[Cecil Mannering]].Palmer p.874 The film's title is an allusion to the poem ''[[Kissing Cup's Race (poem)|Kissing Cup's Race]]'' by Campbell Rae Brown. A [[jockey]] manages to escape a gang of kidnappers and makes it to [[Sandown]] in time to win his race. ==Cast== * [[ Harry Gilbey]] as Squire Heatherington * [[Chrissie White]] as Chrissie Heatherington * [[Cecil Mannering]] as Jack Heatherington * [[Alec Worcester]] as Richard Cardew * [[John MacAndrews]] as Ingham - the Trainer * [[Flora Morris]] as Daisy Ingham * [[Bobby Ingham]] as Arthur - the Boy Jockey ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Palmer, Scott. 2,500 (auditorium) | tenants = [[Knoxville Knights]] ([[Eastern Hockey League|EHL]]) (1961–1968)

[[Knoxville NightHawks]] ([[Professional Indoor Football League|PIFL]]) (2012–2013) | embedded = | website = [http://knoxvillecoliseum.com/ knoxvillecoliseum.com] }} '''General James White Memorial Civic Auditorium and Coliseum''' (usually shortened to '''Knoxville Civic Coliseum''') is a multi-purpose events facility in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], owned by the Knoxville city government and managed by SMG. Its components are an auditorium with a maximum seating capacity of 2,500,{{citation |url=http://www.knoxvillecoliseum.com/default.asp?lnopt=6&pnopt=0 |title=Auditorium Technical Information |publisher=Knoxville Civic Auditorium and Coliseum |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405063843/http://www.knoxvillecoliseum.com/default.asp?lnopt=6&pnopt=0 |archivedate=2012-04-05 |df= }} a multi-purpose arena with a maximum seating capacity of 6,500,{{citation |url=http://www.knoxvillecoliseum.com/default.asp?lnopt=6&pnopt=1 |title=Coliseum Technical Information |publisher=Knoxville Civic Auditorium and Coliseum |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405063830/http://www.knoxvillecoliseum.com/default.asp?lnopt=6&pnopt=1 |archivedate=2012-04-05 |df= }} an exhibition hall and a reception hall. It was built in 1961.{{cite web |url=http://www.knoxville.com/news/2009/apr/21/knoxville-attraction-james-white-memorial-civic-au/ |title=Knoxville Attraction: James White Memorial Civic Auditorium & Coliseum |author= |date=21 April 2009 |work=[[Knoxville News Sentinel]] |accessdate=30 November 2011|archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1322712187YZVKSBPEFB?url=http://www.knoxville.com/news/2009/apr/21/knoxville-attraction-james-white-memorial-civic-au/ |archivedate=1 December 2011}} The arena is home to the [[Knoxville Ice Bears]], of the [[Southern Professional Hockey League|SPHL]] and the University of Tennessee Ice Vols, of the [[American Collegiate Hockey Association|ACHA]]. In the past, the arena hosted the Knoxville Speed, of the [[United Hockey League|UHL]], the [[Knoxville Cherokees]], of the [[ECHL]] and the Knoxville Knights, of the [[Eastern Hockey League|EHL]]. It was also the home of the Tennessee Thundercats professional [[indoor American football|indoor football]] franchise, for two years. It was the main home arena for [[Smoky Mountain Wrestling]], a regional wrestling promotion, run by pro wrestling [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame|Hall of Famer]] Jim Cornette, from 1992 to 1995. Performances hosted in the facility have included [[circus]]es, plays and [[musical theatre|musical]]s, [[symphony orchestra]] concerts, popular music concerts, and comedians. On March 18, 1982, the venue was notable to be the site of [[Randy Rhoads]]{{'}} final show, before his death in a plane crash the very next day.http://www2.gibson.com/News-Lifestyle/Features/en-us/spotlight-0319-2011.aspxhttp://www.ozzyhead.com/randbio.htm [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]] broke the record (at that time) for the fastest sellout to a concert at the Coliseum for their August 26, 1971, performance. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{official website|http://www.knoxvillecoliseum.com/}} {{SPHL}} {{Smoky Mountain Wrestling}} {{Coord|35.965316|-83.911653|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Tennessee]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tennessee]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Music venues in East Tennessee]] [[Category:Professional wrestling venues in Tennessee]] [[Category:Sports venues in Knoxville, Tennessee]] [[Category:Performing arts centers in Tennessee]] [[Category:1961 establishments in Tennessee]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1961]] [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] {{Tennessee-stadium-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Parallettes.jpg|thumb|197px|right|A set of parallettes constructed from PVC pipe.]] {{unreferenced|date=April 2014}}
'''Parallettes''' are small [[gymnastics]] devices, employed in pairs, used primarily to simulate the [[parallel bars]] that can be found in professional [[gymnasiums]]. Parallettes are similar to pushup bars, or [[dip bar]]s, but they are generally longer and lower to the ground.
Aside from their appeal as equipment for gymnasts, parallettes are also appropriate for other athletes who wish to develop strength by means of bodyweight exercises.
Typical exercises done on parallettes include [[L-sit]]s, V-sits, handstand presses and [[handstand pushup]]s. Body weight is always supported on the hands, but some parallette exercises are excellent core and leg strengtheners as well.
Although parallettes can be purchased from a number of commercial sources, they are simple to fabricate from commonly available materials such as [[Polyvinyl chloride|PVC]] pipe. Consequently, both professional and home gyms will often utilize low-cost, "homemade" parallettes.
==See also== *[[gymnastic ring]]s
==External links== *[http://www.parallettes.net/wp-content/uploads/2010/10/ParalletteConstruction.pdf PDF instructions for homemade parallettes]
{{Gymnastics-stub}} [[Category:Gymnastics apparatus]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Ratcliffe Stadium | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | former_names = Fresno State College Stadium
(1926–1941) | location = 1101 E. University Ave
[[Fresno, California]] | coordinates = {{Coord|36.768|-119.789|region:US-CA_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | opened = October 9, 1926
{{Time ago|1926}} | renovated = 1976, 1986, 2009 | expanded = 1942 | owner = [[Fresno City College]] | operator = Fresno City College | surface = [[Playing field|Field]]: [[grass|natural grass]]
[[Track and field|Track]]: polyurethane | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | capacity = 13,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Fresno City College Rams]] }} '''Ratcliffe Stadium''' is a collegiate athletic venue in the [[Western United States|western]] [[United States]], located on the campus of [[Fresno City College]] in [[Fresno, California]]. Opened {{Time ago|1926}} in 1926, it was renamed in 1941 after their first football coach, Emory Ratcliffe. The stadium hosted the [[Raisin Bowl]] {{nowrap|(1946–1949)}} and was home to the [[Fresno State Bulldogs football]] team through [[1979 Fresno State Bulldogs football team|1979]]; they moved to their on-campus [[Bulldog Stadium]] in [[1980 Fresno State Bulldogs football team|1980]]. Ratcliffe also hosted the [[West Coast Relays]], a major [[track and field]] competition. Today, local [[high school football]] games and various track and field events are still held there. The stadium has a [[seating capacity]] of 13,000, and it is located at 1101 E. University Avenue, along [[Blackstone Avenue]]. The football field has a conventional north-south alignment, at an [[elevation]] of {{convert|300|ft|round=5}} above [[sea level]]. ==Historical events== On June 2, 1964, Fresno Mayor Wallace D. Henderson marched with [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] and 1,000 persons from Fresno High School march Ratcliffe Stadium, where about 3,000 persons attended a rally that he spoke at regarding fair housing, desegregation and the Rumford Housing Act and in protest of [[California Proposition 14 (1964)]]. It was organized as the Witness of Faith for Freedom Rally. ==See also== * [[Save Mart Center]] * [[Chukchansi Park]] ==References== * {{cite web | | title=Ratcliffe Stadium | url=http://www.fresnocitycollege.edu/index.aspx?page=913 | publisher=Fresno City College | date=2010 | accessdate=18 August 2010}} {{Fresno State Bulldogs football navbox}} [[Category:American football venues in California]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in California]] [[Category:Fresno State Bulldogs football]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:NCAA bowl game venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1926]] [[Category:Sports venues in Fresno, California]]

Powell Convention Center''', also known as the '''Ocean City Convention Center''', is a multi-purpose [[convention center]] in [[Ocean City, Maryland]], [[United States|USA]]. It contains {{convert|214000|sqft|m2|-3|abbr=on}} of floor space.{{cite web|title=Floor Plan|publisher=Roland E. Powell Convention Center|url=http://ocmdconventioncenter.com/files/8014/4977/3874/OCO-2015-21298_Convention_Center_Floor_Plans_for_Web.pdf|accessdate=March 5, 2017}} It can also be converted into a 5,000 seat [[indoor arena]] that can host sporting events, like [[wrestling]], as well as concerts. It is named after former mayor of Ocean City, [[Roland E. Powell]]. Food and beverage, catering, and special event services are provided by [[Centerplate]]. ==External links== * [http://ocmdconventioncenter.com/ Roland E.
